150696128.review:
A fantastic RPG for anyone who likes long and well-crafted storytelling experiences. I cannot recommend this game more to anyone who enjoys games like Final Fantasy, Octopath Traveler, and the like.

I got into this game from a friend who recommended it to me, and not once have I regretted starting. A great selling point is that this game doesn't punish free-to-play experiences. Not once do you ever need to spend money in this experience, as the game has a fair distribution of its in-game currency, even if you ignore most of the side content. The free characters that don't require the gacha system are also more than enough to get you through a good portion of the game, at least from my own personal experience.

While some of the content can be tedious to do, the great part is that it's entirely optional. I haven't ran into any situations where the game explicitly forced me to do content I didn't enjoy. Probably the worst part is the back-and-forth that some story quests have, but even then that's manageable due to the fast travel system. None of the side quests lock significant content behind them (at most it's like, a few characters, some character-exclusive weapons/armour and one mechanic related to its questline), so if you don't like something, then you don't have to worry about avoiding it.

With the wide roster of characters, party composition is complex yet seamless at the same time. There are nearly endless possibilities for making your party, and there's no one "correct" team to have at any given point of the game. The variety of the party members you encounter is honestly something unlike any other game I've played so far. There's healers, attackers, tanks, supporters, debuffers, the list goes on. Even among the free characters (the characters that don't need to be obtained from the gacha system), you have a good selection. Just about every free character can become a 5-star, which is the highest and strongest tier of character, so you're never being punished for not using the gacha characters. At worst, you might have a harder time with some of the endgame content, but again, that's optional.

However, I can't really leave a review and ignore any possible downsides the game has. The only notable flaws I've ran into is an occasional crash in some specific circumstances and some texture glitches in cutscenes. The crash can be avoided, however, but the texture glitches cannot be. That may detract from the experience for some people (especially people that are sensitive to flashing imagery), so that is a downside. One nice thing that the game does is that if your game crashes (or is forced to shut down for some reason) during a gacha pull, it saves the results of the pull for when you open the game back up, making it so you don't get your currency wasted.

Despite these issues, I still recommend the game. The story is great, the characters have depth, and it's an all-around amazing experience for RPG fans.

147457069.review:
Steam Time Played: 27 hours
Mobile Time Played: 50+ hours

As long as you don't mind some gacha in your games, this is a really nice game that feels like a wonderful successor to Chrono Trigger. Despite the fact that there are definitely gacha aspects (unlocking new and powerful characters), it feels like it was built as an rpg first with the gacha aspect added on. Really engaging story (though you may groan at dialogue sometimes), simple-but-engaging turn based combat, rich music, beautiful environments, and fun sidequests are just some of the features I enjoy about the game. Moving around took a little bit to warm up to, but once I came to the realization that this is a mobile game first, it becomes understandable and I actually ended up preferring it. 

[b]THAT BEING SAID[/b] I would honestly skip it on PC and download it directly on your mobile device. The initial download on PC is insufferably long, even with a good internet speed, the graphics and gameplay are clearly designed with mobile in mind, and you miss out on the option for watching ads to get more gacha currency on PC. Maybe give it a try on PC if you don't mind the initial download length, but then transfer your account over to the mobile app if you decide to stick with it.

So i recommend the game for the following two reasons.
1. The gameplay is very much like final fantasy turn based.
2. The story is interesting and one well worth actually reading the dialogue.
Where the game is lacking for a gatcha is...
1. The banners show the hero featured, but don't give any indication of what the skills are of that hero.  I have not found an ingame catalog of all the heroes so i can view what all they do.
2. Playing on both a phone and computer is an absolute nightmare.  You have to keep transferring your account back and forth and each time you do it, for some reason the client feels the need to redownload about 1GB of data.
3. Don't expect much in the terms of daily reward mails, gifts, or ingame currency.  Completing the story quests and such will take about 3+ chapters before you have enough for even 1 x10 pull.  The game also offers no pity system.  Most gatcha games give out currency and pulls like crazy, but not this one.  One x10 pull costs around $25.  For a game that offers so many heroes to collect....they really want you to pay for them!
Everything in the game according to multiple sources can be cleared with the free heroes, so my retort is, why even have the gatcha with the low pull rate, no pity, and high cost?  Could earn a lot more money if you gave some deals.

137158018.review:
For a free game, this is SO GOOD! this is definitely got a traditional old school jrpg vibe going on because it got the same writer as Chrono Trigger. even have the same vibes but also different at the same time. Story is great and drawing me in, Soundtrack is awesome, 100% no doubt. 

I'll list some of the good things i like about this game

Battle system has its own strategic elements and also interesting. total 6 people party, 4 front liners and 2 reserves. No recovering HP/MP using items (even outside battles) but by putting units in reserve it will recover them per turn. a LOT of Status Ailments and Status Conditions tho so you got yourselves a lot to memorize later on if you really want to go indepth to this game lmao

You can move to places you're already visiting so it's nice. Inns recover your HP/MP to full. There's weapon and armor crafting system by using material obtained from monsters and or chests. A lot of minigames that can reward you with gacha crystals

The gacha system is not really painful and have forgiving rates for me so far, i got myself a lot of good 5 stars units and honestly you can progress story as long as you keep leveling your 4 stars and above characters and upgrade their equipments. The main character Aldo eventually gets stronger later along with the story progressions so it doesnt hurt to keep his level the same as your other characters. Story characters which Aldo's travelling friends also get stronger later on. You can also get some 5 stars units from a story progression so it's nice. The crystal for doing gacha are farmable thru progressing stories and reaching certain milestones like defeat x amount of x enemies or register x amount of x weapon, reaching chapter x of the main story, etc. 

There is no dupes/duplicates units in this game, instead, dupes pull will be exchanged with other rewards and sometimes increase the star of the same character you're already have if you're lucky. Leveling up characters can be done by usual battle grinds or giving character an exp increasing items.

Each 4 stars and above character have their own side quests so you understand more about the character. The more you progress the story and progress the character levels, the more side quests available. And each side quests rewards you with gacha crystals and unit exp increasing items!

Unlike usual mobile gacha games, this game has no stamina system so you can play this game as long as you like!

The collaboration quests+dungeon are nice in terms of story which weave in to Another Eden world nicely, and rewarded you with free units and some of their signature weapons, although you have to reach a certain point of main story if you want to do them which is not a bad thing imo. And also collaboration dungeon stays available forever so you don't have to worry about missing them! you'll eventually get to do them as long as you do the main story.

The artstyle of the game is cute like a picture book-like style, might not for everyone but i personally love it. Fitting for such a tale. The characters illustration style is awesome.

i'm not experiencing the errors and freezes like other reviews so far and i'll update this if i'm actually experience it later.

My inputs to further improve this game are:
-include a gamepad/joystick support so you can kickback and relax
-include an offline version of this game so you don't really need internet to play this game
-(very personalized opinion) add more non-humanoid playable characters like Cyrus, Lokido, Nopaew, etc for more species/race diversity in the casts :D

131502474.review:
Another Eden. Originally a mobile JRPG brought to PC. I used to play the game on mobile and now decided to pick up where I left off 2 years ago but on my PC. Good news! You can still connect the game to my gmail account so I don't need to restart all over again.

This game is a JRPG with gacha system (which the worst system to me, but hey! it's free). Gacha system in this game is painful for any F2P player. You only get a bunch of crystals at the beginning, but as you progress through the game, the amount of crystals you get is super low that you'll have a hard time pulling for characters. Good news is, you don't need to get dupes as the game doesn't need you to get the same character more than once to be able to fully upgrade your characters. Any upgrades will be grindable inside the game. Also good news again, you can get many 5 stars characters from side story and recruitment via test fights and many of them were actually better than characters you get from gacha.

The game relies heavily in story telling and is actually one of the best JRPG story I have ever encountered. The side story mostly very good and the main questline really hit hard. The game seriously have a great story telling so I would recommend the game for you story-lover.

Music is superb. No question asked.

Gameplay mechanic is kinda nice and you will play a lot with team composition and strategy. it's old school JRPG mechanic but with some depth on it. Balancing your party is a must or you'll get a hard time defeating bosses, even some normal mobs.

The problem with the game lies within the game engine itself. Sometimes, the game closes suddenly and it would be annoying when you're grinding inside dungeons. Opening screen sometimes freezes a lot so starting the game could be a pain (this also applies on the mobile counterpart, so i don't think it's PC only problem).

130663245.review:
Really fun game, addicting. Lots of quests, side quests, character quests, and more quests to do. So many characters! The music is really, very nice! And yes, tons of Tales of, Chrono Trigger, Chrono Cross vibes in this game (with very good reason, and I love it!) 

One really neat Collectible to go around to collect are the kitty cats. You can even choose which one to follow you around as your companion. 

The battle system is smooth, and I love how you swap in and out with the two in Reserve, and everyone gains XP during battle, even if the Reserves don't participate in the battle. When a Reserve character moves up to the frontlines, they activate a special skill, usually ATK Up, DEF Up, Field Activate (fire, for example), etc. It's really fun trying out so many different skills in battle.

One thing for sure about this game, it's so easy to get Distracted by all these bonus stories and Symphony stories, and character quests! There's always something to do. And the Auction House and Treasure Hunting! I'm still getting used to the Bidding System but it's interesting, that's for sure. I love the Treasure Hunting aspect.

Definitely recommend this game, whether you're a fan of turn-based combat or not. It's a free download, lots of characters you get along the way. Game doesn't require any $$ but I tossed them a few bucks anyway, to help support the game. Graphics are very appealing for me, and I find myself sitting here tackling work just listening to the in-game music. 

I have no idea how I racked up 60+ hours so quickly ... haha! I love this game!

I realise I know a lot more about stacking attacks/buffsdebuff multipliers just through playing the game than I do from reading what can be quite complex discussions online. 

Basically,  don't be afraid if you see online discussions about character pulls/mulipliers and wonder whether this is for you. This is the best JRPG I've found since FF7, with story strands that genuinely tug your heart, and the game just keeps pulling you back for more...

EDIT: It seems they have "fixed" an elevation of permissions vulnerability with the latest patch and now wfs64.sys is no longer being blocked by Windows 11. I will update this review in the near future, as it is now playable. Still, this shouldn't have been possible in the first place.

-----------------------

Can't even launch the game. Windows 11 blocks wfs64.sys on the first launch, which seems to be related to the infamous wfsdrv, for being "unsafe" if memory integrity is active. Game cannot launch because of that. Tried on two different machines, same results. Turning off memory integrity allows the game to launch. However, I'm NOT turning off memory integrity for this game, as this would be a security risk. It's also impossible to just turn it off while playing the game - memory integrity cannot be re-enabled until wfs64,sys is completely gone from your machine, so you need to completely uninstall the game first.

Also, this makes me believe that the reports of wfsdrv doing suspicious stuff on your machine are true, since Microsoft themselves have blacklisted it.

So, basically, while the game looks great and I really wanted to play it, I cannot recommend it - it currently seems to be a security risk and I can't even play it without putting my machines at risk.

[b]Note:[/b] I mostly played the mobile game version which has far more time invested than the Steam version. While I do "Recommend" this game, let it be known that Another Eden does have issues that can make it difficult to fully enjoy.

[b]To Newcomers:[/b] The download servers for Another Eden are terrible, regardless of version (Steam vs Mobile). It takes forever to initially download, regardless how powerful your own internet is. This tedious download process can also repeat itself when AE receives updates, so this can definitely put off potential players.
--  I would suggest waiting it out, as Another Eden is an amazing game with a great soundtrack, story, and characters.
-- Despite being a "gacha," its far more of a JRPG. I dare say AE may be most of the best gacha games out there since there is no real "time-limited" events one has to worry about, which includes its collabs. Just play the game at your own pace and enjoy!
=== Just know that just like a JRPG, AE can become rather grindy once one begins to reach the end-game. At least one doesn't have to worry about time limitations!

[b]To Steam Users:[/b] Yes, Another Eden is indeed a great game and is worth playing. The ability to move around using WASD and using some hotkeys to open certain menus is great, but for combat I would probably stick to the standard mouse controls.
-- However, I would recommend the mobile version instead due to the "free" Chronos Stones via login and viewing of ads. While the Steam version still as the 20 daily stones, the mobile version has an extra 10 by checking the Chrono Stone and watching an ad with potential extra stones by watching extra ads.
=== This may not be an issue to those who have spare cash to spend, but for those wanting to remain purely Free-2-Play, it is advised to play the mobile version for extra Chrono Stones.
=== However, if pure efficiency is not an issue for you, you want to play Another Eden on a larger screen, or you don't have a compatible mobile device, then by all means just play the Steam port. It's still an excellent game!

[b]Other Comments:[/b]
-- The Party UI needs work. Having to scroll through all of your characters to find someone sucks.

123515066.review:
I came back to edit my review later after the roughly 150 hours it took to unlock Grasta, a central mechanic of upgrading your characters past the level cap, because the third arc of the game wow'd me all over again and I feel the need to make sure that everyone who might enjoy this outlier of a mobile game has a chance to. If this game looks interesting to you, [b] do yourself a favor and try it! [/b]  

Another Eden is an anti-social mobile RPG that rejects the annoying trappings that plague the genre. For the kind of person who wants these unique games with zero interaction with others, it's perfect.

With the exception of a few specific roadblock bosses (Tower of Time's boss and the Beast King in the "early" game), most fights can be cleared through clever play and good planning. This might not sound like a standout feature, but these are mobile games we're talking about, this isn't really the norm. You can squeak by with terrible equipment and an underlevelled party if you so choose. No damage scaling based on the level of the gear and the level of the enemy, no gear score, none of that garbage. 

Grinding for something like levels is a non-issue from the moment you're offered more freedom in the game, but certain pieces of gear and the grind for raising the star rarity of characters from 4 to 5 is rather unforgivable unless you're obsessive about doing dungeon runs every day. Easier on mobile to pull out and play whenever, but far less so on the desktop version of the game. That being said, this version of the game allows you to set keyboard shortcuts for anything and everything, and I highly suggest using them for selecting actions quickly in combat and interacting with objects as you explore.

The soundtrack is a huge highlight of the game, and I often find myself turning up the volume when I reach bosses just to hear more of it. Quiet port towns feel serene, abandoned ruins feel lonely and ominous, and the many, MANY battle themes get the blood pumping.

The real star of the show is, however, is the events. From point events to challenge quests, and even the collaborations, every single event the game has ever run is always available. Some are a bit more enjoyable than others, but each and every one feels high effort with original areas, enemies, puzzles, and music. The collaboration characters are also extremely useful. They are more than competitive with many high end characters from the gacha, and fill a wide variety of party roles including being able to set a few of the vital Stance field effects.

There is no skip cutscene button though, so if you're a returning player restarting from around release like I was or if you've not enjoying an event, an auto clicker goes miles faster than the Auto Scroll text. That being said, the writing is usually well thought out and enjoyable. Usually.

121768806.review:
The majority of this is directed to mobile which is the platform I play this on. Google has a character limit on reviews which doesn't really help get the whole point across.

Should you play this game?
Yes on mobile
No for Steam

This is pretty much a full out JRPG that's free to play. All additional content (ie. Episodes and Collab events) are all free. As a lot of JRPGs there is a lot of extra content, sidequests, hidden items and superbosses.

This game seems to be heavily inspired by Chrono Trigger with many references (Chrono Cross included). I personally enjoy it and the similarities but there are differences that makes Another Eden it's own.

Since this game has been out for a few years I never thought there being too much content could be a negative and that's only from the angle that there is so much to catch up on - They've also just added new content around July 2022 so this game still has plenty of life. Some of the episodes and collab events have a points system which gives you rewards at milestones - This is a lengthy process for most if you choose to grind it out. Some can be done in specific areas while a few can only be done in the dungeons requiring keys which replenish over time.

The gatcha element is to roll to get characters. Some characters have different versions which you can switch between. Any duplicate characters will gives you Light or Shadow points - Part of an upgrade system that yields bonuses at certain intervals. For the gatcha you can be F2P the game does give a huge amount at first and as you clear out content it's still generous.

Another part of the monetization is the keys. These are used for dungeons and you get them replenished over time but of course can buy more with premium currency. This isn't really necessary as it is a little time consuming with the free keys over time.

There are 2 subscription packages that each give you perks to the gameplay. You definitely get the best from the more expensive package and the lower costing one is okay - It's nothing special in my opinion. I personally will never spend money on the higher costing package - You really won't feel left out especially since this is a single player game. You can subscribe to both free for the first month to see the benefits which is kind of cool (Just remember to cancel the subscriptions which you can do same day as signing up for).

Now there are some areas of this game that I find annoying. Nothing is perfect so there is usually always something to criticize.
1. Dialogue is LONG. Takes forever and you can't really skip through it (Unless you fail at a boss you can skip the scene to re-engage the boss) but that's it. You can "Auto" the dialogue but it's many times slower than just tapping manually to get through it.
2. The 2 monthly subscriptions are a little confusion to understand at first. They do quite a good job explaining things but I feel on at least mobile the small window size really makes it a bit more difficult to understand the differences.
3. This point is PC specific. I did just have the game open for 5 minutes to leave this review but it did hijack my audio settings to Steam's Audio which no game I've played has even done this before. Kind of invasive IMO.
4. The game doesn't automatically link to your account (On mobile at least not to Google Play) which is kind of lame. This means if you don't take the precaution to establish this you could lose your account permanently. I had to contact customer support and they were able to recover my account thankfully.
5. This point I can't really direct to the devs themselves but it's good to know this. The wikipedias are really weak. The english one has been broken for the last 6 months (Of writing this review in Sep 2022). There are LUA errors on tables so you're missing out on some info. Another wiki is Altema which is Japanese but can be translated to english on a browser. This has poorly translated text which makes searching challenging (ex. Deidre is "Diadora") and has symbols to represent attack types (ex. Pierce or Fire) which cannot be translated.
6. Some storyline quests that I recall had points where there was little direction and had to resort to looking up information online. This kind of ties into point #5 above in that the information is lacking and had to find direction on Youtube videos which are mainly people's "Let's Plays" so you're sifting through an already lengthy video.

118548845.review:
I knew coming in that the combat was going to be childish and cheesy. No high (or even moderate) expectations there. I came for the story.

But where's the story?
The setup in the prologue seems interesting but very quickly you get lost. After you finish the starter zone you suddenly get time-warped into the future. Then after what seems like a bunch of side quests completely unrelated to the main story we were introduced to at the start of the game, we get time-warped again, this time to a distant dinosaur past.

During this time, some side story arcs unlock where you play uber powerful characters. Again, no idea where they are going or if they are related to the main story. You get one short episode and basically a "to be continued".

Some of the side quests are really quite well done -- with an actual mini story played out by characters with real personality and motivations, instead of boring western-game-quest style of kill-X-fetch-Y. And they bother to make cutscenes for everything, making the most of the otherwise primitive/simple 2D side-scroller  interface.
Don't discount this when even recent big-studio titles like AGS's New World can't even do this to make an engaging interaction with the player.

But the lack of well-paced overarching story, combined with constant big updates forcing me to wait for the game to start when I launch it... I really wanted to give it a chance but now it's just another uninstall.

Definition of the word "game":

1) A form of play or sport, played according to rules and decided by skill, strength or luck.  Play means to have fun or for recreation.
2) [verb] to manipulate a situation, typically in a way that is unfair or unscrupulous

Mobile games have a sordid history with a large number of them seeking to manipulate people into paying exorbitant amounts of money for in game items rather than a flat fee like a typical game.

The issue here is that the first definition of "a game," the noun definition, does not apply to this item. It isnt designed to be fun but to create boredom. Everything is a grind, intentionally so. Some of the weapons take more than 2 months just to level up. That mechanic is pervasive in all aspects of the product. The boredom design is a function to goad people into spending money on items that will speed up the boring process.

The second definition, the verb definition, does apply to this product. They are gaming the system by using loot boxes to indirectly get people to gamble money on game items to make it easier, more enjoyable, or less of a grind. They prey on people with OCD, people in the military working away from, among others.

111761630.review:
The base game is offered FOR FREE to everyone, but like all F2P gatcha games it does have a "pay to win" feature.  In this one though, it's not really pay to win but more like pay to go faster with better warriors.  You can absolutely get through the game totally for free, it will just take you longer than it would if you pay for some of the better stuff.  I actually loved this game, even as a free player IT IS FUN.  It's an RPG with an intriguing story and interesting characters (including several crossovers with other games).  The gatcha element lets you grab more warriors for your team, each chance to grab a new character will cost you 100 gems, or you can spend 1000 to get a 10-pack (it seems the 10-pack has better chance to get more powerful people).  You will get 10 crystals for free each day that you log in, plus more for completing story quests and little in-game achievements.  Then there is an option to PAY REAL MONEY for premium gatcha tickets that can give you "premium" characters. 
 So yeah it is a pretty good game, one of the best mobile ports that I've seen.  But...

But it's a 9 GB download and EVERY TIME they make any adjustments to the game (major patch or little hotfix) the game will require a FULL re-download before it lets you play.  I had the game less than a week and there was the original download, then another one on day two, then they wanted another 9 GB on day 4.  So I quit rather than keep re-downloading the game.  I have a limited data plan here, and I live in the boonies so a 9 GB download takes almost six hours.  I literally spent more time waiting for the game to download than actually playing it.  

I hope the developers find a way to optimize their download packets in the future so you only need to download the changes instead of re-downloading THE ENTIRE GAME every time.  But I'm done.  I quit.  I uninstalled it.  It's a fun game once you start playing and get past chapter 4 in the main story, and the side stories are cool, but I'm not all about wasting my day downloading a game that I've already installed TWICE this week.  So let's just say I'm glad this game is free to play - I'm very glad I didn't spend any money on paid gatcha tickets or premium content, because I can't put up with the constant re-download requests. 

But hey, if you're willing to sit through three 9 GB downloads EVERY WEEK, then it's a great little gatcha RPG so you'll have some fun with it.

111221078.review:
I only started playing this game as I am a huge fan of Chrono Trigger and Chrono Cross and wanted to play through the Complex Dream content in Another Eden. I'm recommending it only as the game is free to play and under the assumption you want to play through some of the collab content this game offers.

As I have no long term plans to play the game I didn't bother rerolling or caring what units I started with out of the gacha system. The game has close to 3 years of content at this point, but I only played through the parts of the game (up to about Chapter 22) using the free characters and Persona 5 characters, then used Serge, Kid, and Harle to play through the Complex Dream scenario twice (didn't bother with the 'neutral' scenario which can only be done after Chapter 25).

Pros:
- Nice throwbacks and integration with some of the Symphony content (i.e. fully played through Persona and Chrono Cross collabs)
- The turn-based nature of the battles are more engaging than I was expecting from a mobile game
- Obviously pulls heavy inspiration from Chrono Trigger with characters like Cyrus in the main story and has references to that game pretty consistently throughout the main storyline.

Cons:
- The writing and translations are a bit off. There were multiple places where I noticed spelling mistakes which kind of ruins the narrative for this trying to be a story-driven RPG (things like using the wrong your/you're, there/their, etc.)
- No true controller support hurts and the existing keyboard/mouse setup is awkward. If you can use your mouse with your left hand and keyboard with your right then the default controls aren't too bad though.
- The maps are relatively repetitive likely due to the nature of it originating as a mobile game and there are lots of wasted opportunities for maximizing screen real-estate to keep track of buffs/debuffs and other things.
- You can't even subscribe to the monthly services in this game through Steam even if you wanted to (although apparently they are pretty terrible value unless you play religiously anyways). The crystal purchases are pretty steep and are about the same as games like Genshin Impact (which is also horribly overpriced), but this is offset by 'Guaranteed 5*' banners that are available using paid currency.

110975183.review:
It installs, but fails to launch. It appears to be because it tries to install a system service using a Powershell script and it lacks the permissions to do so. It is also possible that it fails to install because I run Windows with Enhanced Security (Core Isolation and Memory Integrity enabled) and this driver tries to do something shady that is inherently incompatible with Enhanced Security.

Looking around for troubleshooting information, I found a post from the developers saying that this kernel driver (wfsdrv) is needed for anti-cheat features, and the kernel driver, if successfully installed, would be persistent on the system even when the game is not running; uninstalling the game is the only way to remove it. This immediately makes it not worth it for me to play the game on Steam.

I strongly recommend to stay away from this game until they remove the driver or make the install process more transparent. Play it in your mobile phone if you must, unless you don't care about your system security at all.

107505991.review:
Traditional JRPG of the finest caliber. You will forget that gacha is even involved, until very specific moments where the story characters can't keep up reliably. This isn't an issue though...you will get a few choices prior to that to pick additional team members (get Erina, best Supporter early on, if that's not enough at some point, get Serge which is free via the new Chrono Cross collaboration). The currency, Chronos Stones, to summon new characters, is earned along the way and awarded plenty via different tasks.

Most of the time, the story will be easily manageable with the main characters but there's still the gacha-element...which isn't so bad. Pulling the same characters adds shadow/light points, which briefly increase stats and unlock an additional badge/skill slot - but that's overkill usually and not a necessity. You can upgrade characters for free, but there are bottlenecks ofc. If anything negative can be said... there are paid banners usually featuring powerful, new units, which can only be pulled from if you use paid Chronos Stones. Compared to "free" summons, you will have a guaranteed 5 star unit out of those. The downside: Buying Chronos Stones is relatively expensive due to no regional pricing. Prices probably originate from the JP version, and we all know the Japanese got an expensive lifestyle.

Still, even without paying, not a big issue. But be aware you have to farm dungeons quite often, especially for AS characters you might want, but also for the main characters, to upgrade them. Shadow/Light, for the main characters who can not be summoned, can be farmed in Another Dungeons, which is important for the 3-5 reward slots at the end of those dungeons, dropping Badges, Tomes, Materials, Scrolls and Treatises. 

Treasure Chant Scripts even more than Chronos Stones and think ahead who you want to upgrade. There are free 5 star units available via collaborations and others have their unique questlines awarding you with most, if not all, upgrade materials. Farming these Chant Scripts is extremely time-consuming and without rng on your side, you can end up with 1, 2 per month, even if you farmed these little suckers the most efficient way possible. Buy red and green keys weekly if you can and keep farming shadow/light points, even if it's a slog initially. In due time, you will be rewarded for your time.

Now, that the gacha and bottleneck mechanics are out of the way...

Graphics are great, if you don't mind the 2.5d style. If you need graphics like, for instance, the newest entries of the Tales series offer, don't play this game. What's there is animated in a cute way and definitely gives you that early-90s vibe you used to feel from starting a new JRPG back in your early days of gaming.

Artworks are extremely detailed and background stories are plenty as well, adding to the immersion. Sub-Quests are a way of earning more Chronos Stones, to summon more units primarily and to add additional world-building to the realm of Aldo and his comrades. Specific Character Quests unlock new, powerful Skills and should be tackled early for Characters you play with. 

Old content is always accessible. It's not temporary and can be tackled at basically any point in the game, once the requirements are met. A lot of free Chant Scripts can be gathered there, as well as free, usually quite helpful, 5 star characters. Plus: a few more hidden characters you can unlock, mostly free as well without any upgrade costs.

The battle system is well thought out, but due to initial limitations on the Supporter/Debuff side, until you get more characters, often boils down to staying alive as long as you can, steamrolling regular mobs with AoE attacks and use AF whenever you tackle a boss or a mini-boss. Honestly though, not many JRPGs have astounding battle systems...but they usually provide you with the option to mix how you see fit. Due to an immense roster of characters available, you have a lot of ways to tackle the game itself.

Now, the Steam version is botched. Before the last small update, it worked without an issue but now it's back to not working mode.

If you can't deal with that, it's fine. Use Bluestacks or any other Android emulator, or just your phone, to play this gem without any crashes or supposedly shady install files. Probably have like 150 hours on phone on this game, but i'm still not even done with half of the main story since there's things to be farmed and a lot of content you can experience at your leisure. Don't overfarm and enjoy the game. If you want to be OP for whatever reason, you gotta pay. Since there are no leader boards though...not sure why you'd do that except for aiding the developer.

I give this game and its mechanics lots of positive, exciting childhood memories out of a horrible adult lifetime with crippling anxiety, drug abuse and lingering depression around every corner.

The steam version deserves only the 2nd part. No clue why it's that horrible. Sad.

Update: Steam-Version started to work again sometime along the line. It still does not utilize the PC's potential fully and might stutter every now and then, but in general, the PC-experience (provided a new update does not break it) is relatively good.
Regarding controls on PC: Using mouse and keyboard, or just mouse, is something I find preferable. Only using keyboard feels weird for this game.

107505129.review:
I like this game, but I fully understand why it isn't for most people.

At the core of it, it's a mobile JRPG.  The mobile aspects irritate the hell out of me: GATCHA, "Awakenings", and so forth.  It's not as obnoxious as most mobile titles are about it, where you have to upgrade every aspect of every character and ability and piece of gear, but it's not bothering me.  

I've heard it called "grindy."  I don't grind.  There's lots of things to do, and while some quests require multiple runs on a map, that's not grinding.  It is, however, dialogue-heavy, with a rather deep story that includes background on all the toons you draw (I think I have 50 now).  There's lots of quests: story quests, sidequests, character quests (for awakenings), and at least a half-dozen other categories that open up as you progress.  After Chapter 13, a bunch of that opens up, and it didn't take that long to get there.

Now, related to the grind, if you manually force your toons into a higher level than is recommended, you're going to be bored.  Combat is not that complex if you use your imagination, but one-shotting every monster in every map is BORING.  If you keep to your level suggestions, then the synergies and... FUN and challenge of it can be represented.  And also, min/maxing a singular party is not what this is for.  You may have two or three different party load-outs that can handle themselves (I do), and when a toon needs to do a character quest, I boost em to the proper level and we go do it.  Getting to know the toons is fun for me.

I like the graphics (mostly).  I love the soundtrack.  I think the dialogue is amusing, although there is a lot of it.  If "yeah, yeah, yeah, point, click" is what you want, this isn't the one.  There is a very minimal resource-for-money thing in here, but I've never done that either.  It's not like you can do a 10-draw every day, but --again -- I'm not here for that.

While I have a feeling the endgame is going to be a little uncomfortable, I still recommend this.  I hope that helps.

Vendalis

107022695.review:
The game admittedly plays better on mobile, but don't let that stop you.  This game is *fantastic*.  It hits all the marks of the old JRPGS of yore while still feeling modernish.  The story is long and most importantly *full*.  I'm already 60 hours in, and there's so much more to access.

The format does wonders for the longevity and interest of the game.  With hundreds of characters to collect, and dozens of stories to follow, the game doesn't ever really feel it's just a bunch of fetch quests -- unless, of course, you stop to do all of the highly repetitive fetch quests that don't tie in to the story at all.

The first 25 chapters will probably take you around 15+ hours to complete and make up the majority of the "first game," if you will.  The credits will roll and the story wraps up nicely... and then the "sequel" begins.  Additionally, there are multiple complete side stories that branch off from the main game primarily following newly introduced characters.  These are much shorter, but still relatively complete.  Each feels pretty satisfying as if it's its own little side game or standalone DLC using the same character pool and engine.

Mechanically - the game is pretty simple.  It's a gachapon, so if you want good characters, you're going to have to roll for them.  Most of the game is pretty accessible even without rolling staple 5* characters like Cthulhu Nagi that completely change the game.  There are plenty of free rolls, and many of the 4* or 4.5* (4* characters that can be made into 5* ones) characters are still top tier.  There's a little bit of an FF10 sphere grid type thing going on to unlock better stats and more moves.  The attacks themselves work on Pokemon Move Disorder wherein you have to pick your 3 favorites along with basic weapon attacks.  You can change your moves around to any of the previously unlocked ones.  A total of 12 unique attacks per team.

If you like Old JRPGS, this is a god send.  Plenty of play time, decent to good scenario writing, quality music, likable characters, and most importantly -- waifus.  It's a little grindy, but all games are nowadays.  10/10 if you're into this sort of thing.  4/10 if you're not.

106185434.review:
Recommending this game to others is a difficult decision for me to make. On the one hand AE is clearly a passion project by Chrono/Xeno series Director Masato Kato. It's got a classic JRPG story, with good characters, excellent music, and a charming art style all it's own. And while the combat system isn't the deepest thing ever I'd argue that its' still engaging. And then you have the collabs and the staggering amount of content as the icing on the cake.

So what's the problem? I'd say it's mobile game aspects do the game a disservice. Not so much the Gacha because you get plenty of really stellar free characters and plenty of free currency to throw around. It more has to do with the RNG and the limiting of access to certain content. Tying RNG into gear is one thing but when it's tied into character upgrading it has the potential to become a problem late into the story when all your units are capped at 60. The general grind for certain things is also pretty gross. But such is the reality of mobile games. They're designed to be accessible but ultimately the primary goal is to make money.

So while I can recommend this game it's a wary recommendation. You might love it, you might hate it. With it being free to play what have you got to lose?

Update: A minor update to this old review. I really have to give it to WFS. They're trying so hard to make their fanbase happy. Adding QoL features, trying to stream line the process of updating units by offering more opportunities to get upgrade materials, giving away free stuff hand over fist, adding more awesome free characters to the roster so people don't feel compelled to pull, I can't say enough nice things about them. They really do love this game and it's community and it shows. Above all that though I've just really enjoyed my time with the game despite my earlier misgivings above.

The music, the characters, the stories, the overall sense of adventure is what truly keeps me coming back. I love this world and it makes me sad that it'll all be gone someday so I say enjoy it while you can. You've got nothing to lose but time.

106126362.review:
Probably one of the best free JRPGs out there. Even a good deal better than some paid ones, though it lacks real depth of gameplay.

Some people call it a spiritual successor to Chrono Trigger/Chrono Cross, and they're not wrong; much of the team, including Yasunori Mitsuda (hence the wonderful soundtrack), worked on it. There's time travel and alternate dimensions. There's a talking frog warrior (who speaks with a familiar soundbyte). There's a brick-and-iron time/dimension hub with beams of light to travel around and a bucket. As of this review, ACTUAL CHARACTERS FROM CHRONO CROSS ARE IN IT. So, yeah, stuff's there.

Pros:
 - THE SOUNDTRACK IS AMAZING.
 - You can play through the whole thing without paying a dime.
 - The artwork is (mostly) great.

Cons:
 - It's a gacha game; it wants you to spend money on a premium currency to do things like get characters. You will earn some throughout the game, but very slowly (especially later on).
 - Somewhat basic combat system. Besides the basic "Attack/Run" options (no in-battle items), there's some sort of "combo" system that eventually unlocks, but it's never clearly explained, seems random, and...doesn't seem to help that much.
 - Story is largely derivative of Chrono Trigger/Chrono Cross, and it's not subtle.
 - Hundreds of characters, so very few of them get any real development (see also: Chrono Cross, but worse).
 - Tropes on tropes on tropes on tropes. There's nothing new to be found with this game - just novelty.
 - Some animations look wonky on larger screen (the sprites are all "paper dolls").

All-in-all, a really solid free JRPG, but in itself not a "great game" - just maybe one of the greatest of its kind (free mobile gacha port).

106079273.review:
First off, i grabbed this game with a simple reason... cats. That's before i found out the game is directed by the guy (Kato Masato) who helped wrote Chrono Cross, Chrono Trigger and Xenogears. And yeah, was pretty hyped up with that 2nd info since those are the games i loved. But all those excitement ends here...

This game is literally unplayable unless you lowered your PC's security level to... practically nothing. Yes, for those who can't start the game (game silent crashed as soon as you start the game). It's because it tried to install something to our System32 folder and was blocked by windows default defending system, it then tried to change files and get into our system kennel and that attempt is blocked too... Further check on the internet shows that the devs claimed that is their "anti-cheat" driver. But breaking down that driver file shows nothing but malicious behavior. Example, the "driver" running outside the game (it starts as soon as you turn on your PC and logged into windows even without the game running), and logging every single of your key press and send it to the developers (which includes the password you type OUTSIDE the game). Really, after a few hours of trying to get this game to work... I ended up with a dilemma to whether "allow" it to work or simply "give up" on the game. And yeah, the decision is obvious when a game try to install a keylogger and try to get into your system kennel at the same time, they have totally no rights to do so and it's pretty much against privacy laws... Normally one will suggest you to play the game on an android device or emulator instead, but... if a game company is doing all these fishy shady moves, no matter the platform we uses it's still that same company... my advise is to stay away from this game for your own safety unless they came up with a way to "anti-cheat" without keylogging and trying to log in our system kennel and starts outside the game even without us playing the game. If you don't mind some malicious "driver" that logs itself into your system kennel and start collecting every single key you press on the keyboard, including all sorts of personal info and your passwords... then go ahead and give this game admin permission or disable your security to let it run. imho, it's not worth the risk. 

P/S: If it's safe, your anti-virus / security defender will not block it in the 1st place. (And it's blocked by windows default security, meaning Microsoft themselves blacklisted this game's "anti-cheat" driver marking it as unsafe.)

104941398.review:
Another Eden is a good JRPG, with special appeal for that subset of RPG players that love to grind. Yes, the game is directed by Takashi Tokita (Chrono Trigger, Chrono Cross), and some of the music is composed by Yasunori Mitsuda (Chrono Trigger, Chrono Cross), and the game is thematically similar to certain classic JRPGs (Chrono Trigger, Chrono Cross). With all that talent, there might be a significant group of people out there content to play through Another Eden's halfway decent story and then just move on. Believe it or not, this game is merciful enough to let you do that without paying a cent. While the gacha system utilized by this game's cash shop enjoys its share of rightful infamy, I found it to be rather generous in dispensing great characters with the currency I got for free, plus the game passes out free characters every event that are especially useful gapfillers for your party, particularly the characters it gives out during crossover events with other games (like Chrono Cross). Steam players don't have the ability to watch ads for cash shop currency like mobile players do, but I still found myself waiting to run into a premium content wall that never came.

While Another Eden offers a broadly appealing JRPG experience for the very reasonable price of free, the real star here is the grind. The entire endgame is about grinding and only grinding. You grind your way to max level, then you grind for materials for better and better weapons. Then you grind materials to unlock new classes and skill trees. Then you grind materials in tougher maps for even better weapons. Then you grind to boost the weapons themselves. You grind your goddamn face off until all that's left of your head is the back wall of your skull and then maybe, JUST MAYBE, you'll be ready to take on your grandpa.

In summation, Another Eden is a good JRPG, free, and sporting a nonintrusive cash shop. There is a ton of content to play through already, with more always on the way. There's enough story and challenge to please casual fans of the genre and enough endgame material to keep free players zoning out in comfy, grindy bliss for literal years. 103595175.review:
Another Eden is a spiritual successor to Chrono Trigger and Chrono Cross with some members of the original team (like Masato Kato and Yasunori Mitsuda) onboard, a love letter to jRPGs of the 90s with a modern feel.

The game itself is massive and is similar in scope to live-service MMOs, except Another Eden is a purely single-player 2.5D jRPG. New story content for it is still being released on a regular basis, expanding it even more with each new update.


[h1]=GAMEPLAY=[/h1]

The gameplay here is of a classic turn-based jRPG with random encounters and limit breaks (called Another Force here). The biggest difference from the classics is that this game has gacha mechanics for acquiring additional characters, each of which has their own set of story quests. The amount of stones for pulls the game gives its players is pretty generous though, the pulls contain only characters and nothing else, and newer banners always provide a small chance to obtain any of the characters featured in the past. Additional styles or class upgrades for owned characters can be unlocked through farming certain in-game resources instead of pulling for them, and the characters that can be unlocked as rewards for story progression can be quite powerful as well, especially the ones from 'Tales of', 'Persona 5' and 'Chrono Cross' collaborations. Unlike character banners, story and crossover events don't expire (except for the Chrono Cross one, which has a 5-year license, but hopefully they'll be able to extend it).
Overall, the gacha mechanics here are not as annoying as in other gacha games, though unlucky pulls can still be quite frustrating at times.

Another gameplay feature that makes this game stand out from other jRPGs is its heavy focus on buffs and debuffs. During its harder boss fights the game becomes akin to chess with strategic moves and countermoves planned for a few turns in advance in the battle of the opposite elements using specifically tailored equipment. This can sometimes bring previously unused characters into battle, as many of them have their own unique set of buffs and debuffs for a specific element that can be essential in particular fights.

Due to the constant stream of more powerful characters emerging through gacha it is pretty hard for the developers to keep the older content's difficulty balanced, but there is content for regular players (such as the main story quest or episodes) as well as optional content that can challenge even the strongest character teams.

There are various other things to do in the game, like crafting, running "another dungeons", fishing, performing in theater etc. Completionists may find some of those side activities to be rather grindy, but the game's variety never fails to impress.


[h1]=STORY=[/h1]

The story feels like a mix of Chrono Trigger and Chrono Cross, ranging from silly and light-hearted to serious and heavily emotional, and like the rest of the game it is very character-driven. Those who enjoy Kato's works will feel right at home. In addition to the main story that revolves around time travel there's a bunch of side episodes set in various eras. These additional stories often provide a refreshing shift in narrative thanks to Takeru Sakurada's engaging writing that creates a different and unique feel for each of the episodes he writes for.

While Another Eden's story already contained some references and allusions to the Chrono series, the collaboration with Chrono Cross (also written by Masato Kato) makes the tie-in official.


[h1]=MUSIC AND SOUND=[/h1]

The soundtrack is incredible, one of the best in the genre, and it currently spans across 11 (!) CDs. Various composers that worked on this game created some truly amazing pieces in many different styles. This is my nominee for Best Soundtrack for The Steam Awards 2021.

The game has occasional voice acting, most of which happens in the form of battle shouts and character introductions (with a few exceptions), but it is possible to switch between English and Japanese voices.


[h1]=GRAPHICS=[/h1]

The game looks surprisingly good for a 2.5D title, with nice animations, beautiful backgrounds and gorgeous character arts. The subtle use of 3D elements here makes everything seem almost purely 2D, but once characters move towards or away from the screen the 3D effect becomes noticeable and it looks quite impressive.


[h1]=PC PORT=[/h1]

This game was originally made for mobile phones and touch screens, and it shows. While it is more convenient to play it on a PC with a big screen, this version still leaves a lot to be desired. Every time the update is released or the account is transferred the game deletes and redownloads 8.5 GB of data on PC (which takes ages), while it's only around 150 MB on my phone taking less than a minute. There are certain crashes here and there. Performance is decent but could've been better, especially in terms of responsiveness. An SSD might help mitigate this to some degree. That being said, developers are actively working on bug and performance fixes, so the state of the port improves at a steady rate.

Mobile versions also have daily ads that provide additional stones for pulls while the PC port does not, and the recently introduced paid subscriptions can only be activated through a phone as well. It is possible to transfer account between platforms, however, and subscriptions work fine on PC once activated. Still, it would be much better to keep both platforms synced without having to go through the account transfer process every time.


[h1]=CONCLUSION=[/h1]

Another Eden is undoubtedly a labor of love. It doesn't use any predatory tactics to empty your wallet with its gacha mechanics, nor does it advertise or nag you about any of its paid features, as the main focus here is to provide great gameplay experience. For a free-to-play title everything here is fairly balanced. It's possible to play it like any other jRPG, gathering stones as rewards for story progression and using them to get more characters from pulls.

It still surprises me how the game of this magnitude and talent is not so well-known still. I recommend anyone who loves classic jRPGs and especially fans of the Chrono series to try this game out. Just keep in mind that currently the PC port may not be the best way to experience it.

101057918.review: Another Eden is a game that incorporates all the typical elements from modern gacha JRPGs, while still keeping unique and original. This is done through many multiple mechanics and gimmicks, from the larger things (such as the front line and the backup party members, or Another Force) to smaller things like fishing and guiding light / luring shadow. As you progress through the game, you unlock more and more of these mechanics, keeping the experience fresh and new. Another thing that I think differentiates this game from the millions of other gacha JRPGs is its Another Style (and now Extra Style) characters. Essentially, to not end up with the all-too common issue of having an absurd number of characters, the game introduces new, stronger forms for the same characters with just the right number of differences to be unique, but still clearly the same basic character. The game even has a system in place that allows you to upgrade your characters in the case that your luck (or lack thereof) with the gacha pulls just isn't cutting it (although I will mention that it is quite tedious), as well as an easy method of grinding that allows newly-pulled characters to be brought up to speed in very little time. There's always stuff to do, and more playable content is added often, so if you're looking for a JRPG that'll last you awhile (especially if you're on a budget), Another Eden makes an excellent pick.

99847184.review:
I actually started playing this game on Android since early March this year (still playing till now on Android) and it's been very rewarding and fun, even though Im just a F2P. By the time I wrote this review, I'm already at chapter 82 (the last updated main story is chapter 84). Here's the pros and cons of this game:

Pros:
1. Less RNG, balanced system
Even though there's no pity in this game and the rate is a bit low, it's easy to farm the chrono stones esp if you love grinding (WFS also by far the most generous gacha company I know as it often gives free 5* campaigns alongside with free chrono stones just by progressing or unlocking new story part or from daily login or even watch ads (not available on steam sadly)). 90% of the characters in this game can be upgraded to 5* (Just need to farm (or for some, just do their stories) the item to upgrade them) and all chara (incl the story charas) r all OP. U dont need certain gacha charas to defeat certain bosses just to be able to progress the main story. This isnt a Pay to Win gacha game, however, to play this game (whether ur Pay to Win or F2P, well, esp F2P, required good strategy building and reading ability (as u need to mix-match charas in ur party and their skills and make a strategy from there) 

2. No time limited event
This means that every new events, new charas, or new domains/dungeons once released will be permanently in the game and you can enjoy it with your own pace. New characters upon released will have a special banner where their gacha rate r increased but once that's over, the so-called charas will join the standard banner and you're still able to get them again.

3. Great story, art, and soundtracks
As the game page said, the story writer is the one who wrote the timeless classic JRPG, Chrono Trigger, so you can expect the story will be epic and worth your time. Although it's not 3D (it's hand-drawn and 2D to keep the classic side), the background art r fabulous and beautiful, very well-made. Soundtracks are also awesome

Cons:
1. No skip, fast forward, or auto-play function
This can be a bummer for those who dont really like to read as the dialogue can be pretty long (and a bit dilly-dally). Although in some story events, you can skip the scenes, most of the dialogues in the main story can't be skipped, or fast forward, or auto-play

2. Can't sell unused weapons (cluttered inventory)
Not sure why but the game doesnt have the system where you can sell your unused weapons or armors to the blacksmith npc. Hence, expect for a cluttered inventory. There's no filters for items too, so if you're looking for specific items, u need to scroll down your inventory and find the so-called item manually

Last thing to be remembered, this game isnt a "kid" game that you can just press button and brute force everything (if you did, most likely you can't beat main story bosses and then your review will be "this game is unplayable"), it requires strategy and make advantage of the skills that each of your chara have. No matter whether you will be a Pay to Win or F2P, if you're thinking to just press attack, no strategy, believing that you will win, this game isn't for you. 

Overall, it may not be following the open-world trend but it's so refreshing to see a modern touch in a timeless classic JRPG like Another Eden that combines traditional hand-drawn arts with beautiful CG effects and amazing soundtracks.

Honestly, I enjoy Another Eden. I'd been enjoying it on a mobile emulator for some time before it got a PC port and am enjoying it as a PC port. The game itself is fine, though the writing could use tweeks for maturity and the gameplay could use a little bit more complexity. However, it's a fun enough way to kill time. So... Why am I voting it down? Well... There are a couple of things.

When I first installed, to allow the game to even start I had to go through several steps which I'm pretty sure most of you are aware of. The game occassionally crashes randomly without any sort of message on why and says it's not responding at times when it's loading. I blame my heavily outdated PC for the latter but for the former I consider it a technical issue which needs addressing. 

Unlike most people, I do not mind the dub for the most part outside of... A couple of exceptions. Mostly Miyu at this point though I wasn't fond of Fienne's VA either. However, even though I'm fine with it, I would have liked the option to switch between Japanese and English VA work. The material is there, the devs just didn't include it into the port for some reason. More of an issue is that the Tales of crossover for some reason hasn't had the VA work for its content included into the port. This part I find... Rather disappointing. It makes playing through it significantly less enjoyable than I recall it being on an emulator.

In terms of little things, while the port does allow you to do most things using the keyboard, I do feel like there is more work needed. I would like the menu to be accessible and navigable using the keyboard itself. I would also like notices, episode information and dream information to appear in the game itself rather than requiring to open the browser. Lack of the chrono stones you could acquire through advertisements on mobile also bugs me. 

So... Why am I playing the PC port when I prefer the emulated variant because, outside of the navigation part, it has none of these issues? Well, the PC port on its own chews less resources. The emulator itself is an additionally resource intensive object on my already outdated PC. It is easier on my PC and on my sanity to be running the steam port for periods of time than it is to run it on an emulator on my PC. I also have to admit, I cannot imagine enjoying it as much on a mobile phone either. So the PC is still my preferred place to play it.

The game's core functions still work fine and it's a fun enough game. It just has issues which would improve my experience significantly if fixed.

Update: It seems that the issue which was causing the crashes had been fixed with the update as it does not seem to have happened since. That could, of course, be circumstance however it seems unlikely. I'm not sure what to do with that section of it and have opted to leave it in for posterity's sake.

96678834.review:
Another Eden is a single-player mobile game that features a script written by Masato Kato. It is a turn-based RPG that features a Gacha pull system to gain access to more characters. This might remind you of Genshin Impact, but unlike Genshin, there are no multiplayer aspects at all. The Gacha might turn some away, but you can actually do quite well with the free-to-play characters.

The game begins with a baby in a forest who is found by Beast, who notices the baby’s internal dormant power. However, before he can really interact with the baby he senses other humans approaching.  An older man spots the child and a younger boy comes out from hiding in the bushes. Some time passes, both children have been taken in by the old man and are now young adults. From here, you go on a quest to create a birthday present for the older man who rescued you.

This quest, of course, leads to everything going wrong. Your sister is kidnapped, you discover a cat that can travel between different dimensions, and you find a magical sword. Eventually you are even transported into the distant future. Now you are on an epic journey where you and your party travel through different areas doing quests and adventuring.

The combat of the game is your typical turn-based RPG. You have a party of characters that you can either obtain by natural progression or through the Gacha pulls. These characters have different abilities and focuses that make them unique from each other. As your character’s level increases, you can unlock new abilities and become even stronger.

There is a lot about the game to enjoy. The story that I experienced so far is really well done. I wish there was some more voice acting than what is included. I guess since it was originally a mobile game there are some limitations there. The music and sound design is solid as well. The Gacha element isn’t super strong, which is nice for a free-to-play game. From what I have experienced so far, and from what I have heard, the game is very free-to-play friendly. 

There have been some rumors and speculations that the game does include an Anti-Cheat software. However, this seems to have some Malware type functionality included. This is definitely a bit concerning, but it passed the checks in place from Steam to be in the store. I would prefer them to charge $15-$30 for the game instead of Gacha in a purely single-player game. This would limit the need for an Anti-Cheat software to be installed on your system all together. It just makes more sense to have Gacha in a game that features some form of multiplayer element.

I was actually pretty surprised at how strong the game is for being a free-to-play mobile game released on PC. There are even a few collaboration events with other games such as Persona and the Tales of series. The combat is straight forward, the design of the characters are nice, and the environments are well done. The more I played the game on PC, however, the more I just wanted to play on the phone instead. If it were on the Switch, I feel like it would be a perfect home for this type of game. I would say this game is worth checking out if you are looking for a traditional RPG. Especially since it is free!

Empecé a jugarlo desde el móvil, quizás hace ya casi un par de años. 

Estéticamente no me llamaba mucho la atención, prefiero los personajes detallados y grandes mucho antes que los chibis. Pero bueno, tampoco están tan mal hechos. (Los dibujos sí, 10/10)
La historia pintaba interesante. A pesar de ser un Gacha, es totalmente diferente al resto. 
Seguí jugando por interés de los acontecimientos, y por el buen sistema de combate que tienen. 
Los jefes eran impresionantes, con sus fases y estrategias... por no mencionar la INCREIBLE BANDA SONORA. 
El juego posee CIENTOS de sountracks diferentes! Para combates, situaciones especiales, jefes... 
Me ENCANTA la variedad de melodías. La música intensifica muchísimo cada momento.
Another Eden es un RPG Clásico. Me siento como en aquellos tiempos que agarraba la GameBoy Advance y jugaba algún JRPG interesante. Me otorga la misma sensación... Nostalgia, inspiración...
Cuando escribo esto, he acabado con el primer final de la historia. 25 Capítulos.
Si estás muy metido en la historia, es realmente triste pero bonita. Me ha llegado al alma. 

A pesar de tener invocaciones, no dependes de ellas. Los personajes que reclutas gratuitamente son bastante competentes. 
Es cierto que la obtención de gemas para invocar es bastante tardía, que los rates, al menos en mi caso, no me han dado ninguna maravilla.
Pero siendo como es el juego, te olvidas de los personajes que podrías tener, y centrándote en tu equipo y tus tácticas, puedes llegar a cualquier lugar. 

Recomendado. 
Pero... 
- No está en Español. Una lástima.
- Steam... ¿Por qué no incluyes las voces Japonesas que sí tiene el juego de móvil? ...  
Las collabs con Persona5 y Tales of son geniales. 
Que no se me olvide mencionar... No he visto a otro juego organizando colaboraciones TAN BIEN HECHAS como lo hace Another Eden...
No solo te incluye los personajes de las collabs de forma gratuita, sino que crean una historia, mapas, mazmorras y enemigos exclusivos de la colaboración... 
Desde que completas la de Tales of, el grupo te va hablando en algunas ocasiones... 

En general. Me encanta. 
Como digo, el diseño gráfico no me atrae mucho, pero entiendo que también así tiene un toque de RPG Clásico... 
El juego tiene mucho texto, y no te deja skipear los diálogos... 
La historia es muy buena, pero tiene mucho relleno. 

En fin. Muy buen juego. Es como un JRPG Clásico de toda la vida, solo que adaptado a móviles, con actualizaciones gratuitas y una cantidad de contenido enooorme.

From where to start and where to finish! I am not that great with games so bear with me ^_^;

A fellow steamer mentioned to me that there is a 3 year (we have entered their 4th year of AE) stuff in game for you to do that you will never getting bored and I hope they still introduce some more in the future. The story is written by Masato Kato and music by Yasunori Mitsuda (got the info from wiki). 

What is missing though (which I don't mind that much but I hope that they will add it later) which it "turns off" most players, is the missing of the Japanese characters voices. I am not sure if it has to do with the Global licence and stuff but it is something that I have noticed from steamers that "turn their backs" to the game (not all of them). 

AE (Another Eden), is also a gatcha game but the developers also provide you either with quests and daily login with some free Chrono Stones (Chrono Stones is the currency to use in characters draw, key cards for dungeons-if you want that is as the game provide you with key cards every few hours, continue in case you get defeated in boss fight) so that you can try for new characters. Also as you play, you will encounter free characters that will be added in your team as you move on.

In my opinion, I haven't seen any other JRPG game that has everything in it, [spoiler]fishing, mining, harvesting, help build a village with quests, become a master chef[/spoiler] and many more. What I just mentioned above is very little to describe how amazing this game is with so many things to do. By the way, you don't need to buy Chrono Stones if you don't want to but to tell you the truth, I did purchase some (during special offers) of around €130+ to support the developers and Team because they deserve what they did and do for their players base in the game.

92975129.review:
This is actually the 2nd time I've started this game. I first played this game on mobile when it first launched on mobile. This was during the launch period when Mariel was considered the best 5star and Toova and Mighty were strong offense. Things have changed a lot since then. I lost my mobile account because they did not have a google link at that time. So I'm literally starting from the beginning. 

The only reason I'm willing to do this is because of this game's permanent content system. All events are retained permanently. For every other gatcha game I've ever played, I never see myself as a returning player. So this is the best thing I want to praise about Another Eden. I really like the permanent content and in my opinion, this makes it far better than all the other gatcha games. Just this point alone. 

Secondly, I'm in a minority here but I like the PVE system with no online. I don't want to interact with others when I'm playing a game. I'm an introvert. That means I don't like interacting. If I have to have an online system, that means I will quit the game in a while. So the lack of online is a big plus for me.

So there are 2 big plus points. 

Now for other things I want to comment about :

The story:
I have read a lot of players praise the story line but for me it is just ok. As someone who has played a lot of jrpgs and other games, I find the story of this game just average. You can tell that the more recent gatcha characters are more well developed and are better written. That's probably because of the way the industry works. You get better writers once the game is somewhat established. But the main storyline (to chapter 25) was disappointing to me. I was somewhat invested in Aldo's family story. So the twist in Aldo's identity was something I found irritating. This is actually where I stopped a few years ago.

The grind:
Grinding another dungeon is probably the worst aspect of the game for me. It was what finally made me quit a few years ago and what will probably make me stop once I play a little bit again this year. While I like the old school play in some aspects, especially the lack of online play, I just can't grind anymore. The developers need to learn that a lot of the kids have grown up and we don't have the time to do this. We can't set aside that much time to play your game. Maybe I can do it for a couple of months. But definitely not permanently. Fortunately this aspect has also improved with the addition of the white keys which give a much needed boost. 

But I will probably return once in a while simply because the permanent content system makes it worth it.

The PC steam version :
This is another reason why I came back. I spend much more time on my PC than on mobile. I honestly prefer gaming on my PC. But the way it is now is very laggy, especially when you go into awards to claim stones for achievements. While I appreciate their need to prevent cheating, they really need to improve their code vastly so that there is no lag. I can tolerate staring at a laggy screen for 2 seconds while the award is loading because I am a old school gamer who has used many old devices. A younger gamer would probably not be able to accept it. 

Voices:
Also we want japanese voices. Even if we are not Japanese. Put the Japanese voices on the PC steam version. In my opinion, I don't like English voices in Japanese games so I personally think that they can save money by just not hiring any more English VA for characters in the future. Keep it 100% Japanese voices with English script for English players
