91891158.review:
I've heard about this game back in 2018 and wanted to try it when I heard it involved a couple of key personnel who were pivotal in making Chrono Trigger. Being a huge fan of that franchise, it was a no brainer but I held off on the mobile launch due to murmurings of a Switch port but, that never happened so I took the dive when the Steam version released.
I have to say, for a game made for a mobile audience, it feels like it could pass for a more than decent JRPG that was made for handheld. 
The art is beautiful and full of vibrant colour the pops and the character art is very high quality and pleasing to look at. The music is amazing and was exactly what I was expecting from a Yasunori Mitsuda composed soundtrack.

First of all, I love that the game is a complete experience with NO stamina system, NO auto-play.
The simplistic methods of travel is expected of a mobile game but it has a decent battle system that includes a speed up option and skills to activate. Instead of just 4 main characters who have the abilities to take on multiple classes or jobs, you have a vast cast of Heroes you can choose from to cushion your perfect party composition. Of course, you begin with the main hero and some heroes will join your immediate group through completing portions of the story but, like most (mobile) games, you to obtain more Heroes through a gacha system. Now, I understand that gacha has a negative stigma and most people stay far and away at the mention of it but, hear me out. I hate gacha as much as the next gamer but, the developers specifically made mention (not to forget the numerous YouTube reviews available) that you can beat the game with any characters barring you have a party that is well balanced enough ie. a DPS, Tank, Support and Healer composition.
Just playing for the first few hours should net you over 2K Chrono Stones (the premium currency) and each summoning of 10 Heroes uses 1K so chances of you obtaining enough Heroes of varying classes should be quite high (or I was incredibly lucky lol). I've also noticed that you get 1 free summon for a 1 x Hero a day for 10 days as well as an additional free summon on the 10th day on a separate banner as a new player so I feel the devs are giving you a fair chance to succeed without pulling a scum move to force you to open your wallet.
Moving forward, I really enjoy the main story (so far) and was pleasantly surprised at how interesting the side quests were. I never would've thought that a mobile game took the time to implement actual stories into them (as in Side Quests) but, that's just me.
There is a weapons and armours system here too much like any complete JRPG, although, simplified. According to the community, a level of complexity is added to the weapons system in late game but I've yet to see how that works. As for character progression, there is a simple to understand grid where you spend AP to learn and obtain passive stats and skills. How far you go on this grid depends on the rare quality of your Hero ie. 3 star 4 star or 5 star rarities.
I would end my praises here and fear I may be missing some more features I noticed but forgot to mention  but this game is a breath of fresh air when it comes to mobile games as it seemingly breaks the mold of traditional mobile game tropes and expectations (at least, for me personally).
The gacha is nice but ultimately not shoved in your face which ironically, made me want to utilize it more. Also, every Hero you pull has a back story as they briefly introduce themselves after you've finished pulling your 1 or 10 Heroes. It's quite amazing how much detail goes into it and it's not just the unique heroes, the generic cookie cutter pulls also have a backstory as well!
Anyway, if you're looking for a simple yet engaging phone game that almost passed for a console quality JRPG on Steam, I highly recommend it. It has a legit story, beautiful art and amazing music. You're not getting content gated by a stamina system and there's no shenanigans like an auto-play button or gimmicks like that so you're actually able to enjoy the game. 
Unless that is what you want?
If you're looking for a mobile game with ads all over, auto-play, stamina system and heavy monetization gacha schemes, this game is definitely not for you.

91214839.review:
For a JRPG Another Eden is mmn fairly decent. In nearly every element. 
Story - decent, some twists, some (few so far) teary moments, some funny moments and as major plus from me - it does not dive to deep in the annoying "ecchi" trend. Story characters are ok, but limited in many ways (ditched all after first few gacha pulls + freebies).
Side content - episodes, collaborations etc. enough to do. another plus from me.
Grafics are ok, character designs - some better, some less. 
Music - solid jprg tunes.
Voice? terible english acting without option to switch to original - first major minus. disabled after a while.
Game mechanics and grind? Depens on gacha. Lucky start or solid monetary investment (100€+)? Little to no grind untill later parts of the game. Quite different otherwise. Very grindy after certain monents - plus daily lockouts.
Grind - another very big minus. Game offers a number of timegated dungeons to grind for character and equipment upgrades with miniscule drop chances. Example: Main character starts as 3 star, can be upgraded to 4 and the 5 stars (requires story porgress as well as upgrade materials from said dungeons), but to unlock his full potential... 256 light points, with 20% chance to get 1 after "very hard" dungeon, which are limited to about 4 tries daily. so... less than 1 daily. more than half a year of daily grind (dungeon allowances are capped at 5 so no skipping here) for ONE character. 
And last but not least - gacha. Low chances (und as in many current gacha games getting 5 star is only a beginning, ideally you need to pull 15 copies of character + another style to reach his/her full potential), stupidly high prices (about 45€ for two guaranteed random 5stars) and very little other options. Freebies are there, but few and late game challenges sort more than half of them out. Really MAJOR minus.

91079455.review:
Attempts to funnel private information to the developer with shady kernel level malware, no thanks. This should be removed off steam and people should be filing a class action lawsuit against the developers.

As quoted below.

"%HOMEPATH%\Steam\steamapps\common\ANOTHER EDEN\wfsdrv

This 'wfsdrv' appears to be a malware/spyware kernel-level driver that the game attempts (and fails) to install to the Windows system32 directory. On top of that, it tries (and fails) to bypass User Account Control and also tries (and fails) to bypass Powershell Execution Policy (by default which is RESTRICTED to prevent malicious scripts but they try to set to Bypass and fail).

This is all done outside of a dedicated 'installer' and thus doesn't properly obtain the relevant admin-level permissions to install anything. It tries to bypass the need to do this via PowerShell terminal commands and it is not only unorthodox but may violate Steam policies as well.

All of this is done to force a random unknown kernel-level driver and kernel-level Windows service to be installed on the system without providing proper notice to the user or obtaining authorization prior to doing so.

I popped open a debugger of choice and dug around the driver itself. Seems the usual 'grab as much data as possible and funnel it to the developers. This includes monitoring keystrokes (found references to hook into the keyboard driver at the kernel level) which is all sorts of creepy and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ up. This app should be reported to both Google Play and Steam for violation of GDPR and other consumer privacy protection laws. ```" - Quoted from Leroy Jethro Gibbs below.

90211653.review:
[i]So with all my reviews I add as I go so not only do you get first impression you get to see how it changes as I progress so lets start with first impressions![/i]


[h1]First Impressions[/h1]

ANOTHER EDEN is basically a mobile port as you'll see from the art style and gameplay. So I find it not that appealing but its good enough to give it a try. Thankfully the way the story is told is entertaining but maybe a little cliche for some. Its a turn based JRPG with auto battle. Auto battle in case you didn't know is where a game forces you into battles as you play. To me I can't stand auto battle as I played FFX...

The main issue are the gambling mechanic in a single player game. I agree with the other reviews that it just isn't needed and is GREEDY AND SHAMEFUL. But I hope this doesn't effect my playthrough.



So here all the Pro's and Con's which will be updated as I playthroiugh....

[b]Pro's[/b]

- Potentially interesting story
- Surprisingly good side quests! Even fetch quest end up being meaningful! XD
- They got Persona 5 crossover with quests with all the main characters along with getting the charm and gameplay down really well!
- Somehow they got a crossover with the Tales franchise which includes some of the main characters across a load of their games!
- The main characters are meaningful and at least try to make them worth while.
- Decent variety of characters
- Potentially good skill tree and levelling up system
- Fair amount of enemies
- Easy to pick up and play
- Steam Achievements

[b]Con's[/b]

- Weird install issues makes me wonder why put it on Steam like that?
- Gambling in Single Player. That's a NO NO
- It takes a while to really get into the game. Like 2 hours in I can't even change gear! XD It actually took around 3 hours just to get gear...O.o 
- Feels like its taking off other games to the point where it could be defined as unoriginal. But it at least tries to embrace that with actually doing cross overs so give and take here. 
- Level layout can feel strangely samey. If you look at the map it feels like dajavu after a while.
- Not all side quests are good. They can be so lame that it's like watching a cringey kids show.
- When you are on a side quest the battle you do are completely without the quest characters despite them literally battling with you! Why did they design it like this?! O.O 


I'll leave the summary when I'm confident i can define how good this game is...


Here's the first 16 minutes of ANOTHER EDEN I hope this helps:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CdowPLaVRrA

89977497.review:
A nice take on classic style JRPGs and a must for anyone who liked Chrono Trigger, as it's written and directed by Masato Kato (Chrono Trigger, Chrono Cross, and Xenogears), the main story is great, truly a journey beyond time and space (with lots of cats).

The scenery is very pretty and most places you visit are worthy of a painting, with lots of attention to detail and good diversity, ranging from deserts and volcanoes to futuristic flying cities, each with it's own theme from an amazing soundtrack by Shunsuke Tsuchiya, Mariam Abounnasr and Yasunori Mitsuda. ("Track 27 - True Eden" might be my favorite game song ever).

The gacha system is no problem at all, as it's completely skippable and can be viewed as a bonus, since even the endgame content can be done without it (Specially with the crossover "Persona 5" and "Tales of..." 5* characters), also, there's no "stamina" system, so you can play as long as you want to (except for the dungeons, which require keys, but those refresh for free quite fast).

With all that said, to me this PC port is still not the best version of the game, since the Steam version lacks the japanese voice acting (a must to me) and the daily rewards on mobile are better.

89977394.review:
Please, folks, stop believing liars and idiots on Reddit and Steam Forums.

The Good:
Story is great. Music is great. Gacha is pretty decent (only on mobile version, will get into that later). Rates aren't completely terrible and the banners aren't just out to dick you out of money.  All content as of this writing can and has been done with completely free characters, so the gacha rate doesn't even matter. The battle system is fun and challenging. Nothing is time-limited except for rate-up banners and daily key dungeons, which aren't really super important to keep on top of.

The bad:
The grind is unreal. Takes about an hour to do daily dungeons. But you don't have to do them.
The English voices are...not fantastic in many cases. I'm fairly sure ProZD's "suggestive dialogue" skit is inspired at least partially by Miyu.
The translation ranges from pretty good to absolute gibberish. It's very apparent they have a main translation team for important stuff and an intern that just google translates the side quests.

The Steamy:
On the mobile version you get 20 gacha currency for logging in each day, Then 20 more for viewing an ad, then 10 more for viewing another ad in the chronos stone buy screen, then random rewards for viewing up to 5 more ads. On the steam version you only get the first 20, which cuts your income SEVERELY.
Steam version only has English voices, mobile version has EN and JP. This is a dealbreaker for some.
Steam version runs at 60 fps which is cool.
Steam version, again, uses a kernel-level anti cheat. This is also a dealbreaker for some. But it is ONLY an anti-cheat as far as anyone can tell, and not a particularly intrusive one.
Unlike Mobius Final Fantasy, the last gacha to hit Steam, you can not crossplay mobile and steam seamlessly. You have to clear and transfer your account to each device using a transfer code. It's fairly jank.


Also that guy with all the awards is lying. He did not debug the wfsdrv driver. I, however, did. It is the most stripped down bare-bones anti-cheat I've ever heard of. It actually stops functioning entirely once the game is launched. Its only purpose is to ensure a secure game launch and create a protected sandbox for the game's memory. That is IT. Anyone can claim a program is spying on you. Do not believe it unless they post proof.

Literally everyone gets this product for free lmao.

Yeah no.......    TLDR: play it on bluestacks AVOID steam version at all costs. I'm just going to leave this quote here:

“found a few script files that are interesting, to say the least.

Specifically in: %HOMEPATH%\Steam\steamapps\common\ANOTHER EDEN\wfsdrv

This 'wfsdrv' appears to be a malware/spyware kernel-level driver that the game attempts (and fails) to install to the Windows system32 directory. On top of that, it tries (and fails) to bypass User Account Control and also tries (and fails) to bypass Powershell Execution Policy (by default which is RESTRICTED to prevent malicious scripts but they try to set to Bypass and fail).

This is all done outside of a dedicated 'installer' and thus doesn't properly obtain the relevant admin-level permissions to install anything. It tries to bypass the need to do this via PowerShell terminal commands and it is not only unorthodox but may violate Steam policies as well.

All of this is done to force a random unknown kernel-level driver and kernel-level Windows service to be installed on the system without providing proper notice to the user or obtaining authorization prior to doing so.

I popped open a debugger of choice and dug around the driver itself. Seems the usual 'grab as much data as possible and funnel it to the developers. This includes monitoring keystrokes (found references to hook into the keyboard driver at the kernel level) which is all sorts of creepy and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ up. This app should be reported to both Google Play and Steam for violation of GDPR and other consumer privacy protection laws. ```”

89743867.review:
This is a game I'd really only recommend to those that already know that they enjoy older jrpgs from snes and ps1 era of games. While I enjoy the game for what it is others might not like the style or the fact it doesn't really add anything new to the genre. It does have an enjoyable story, fun characters, great writing, and an amazing soundtrack. 

Also just because this has a gacha in it as a way to pay for its continuous updates over the past 3 years it is not required to do in order to play and finish the game. You'll get plenty of story and side quest characters by just playing the game along with the multiple collab characters from the Tales of series and Persona. You can take advantage of the current pc release event to try and reroll a certain character you'd really like to use with the free 20 summons until may 14.

This game will take you hundreds of hours to see all there is to do, just finishing the first part of the main story alone will probably take you around 30 hours which is from chapters 1-25. As of writing this review I believe there is 74 chapters. and this is not counting all the side quests, side stories, and character stories.

It's not perfect of course. The game is online only even as a single player game so you'll need an internet connection to play. There is a bit of a grind if you want to power up characters, I assume to keep people playing and have things to do between updates. If you do care about collecting all the characters even the rare ones that show up in the gacha it will be nearly impossible to do without putting some money down and paid summons are not cheap but at the very least it guarantees a 5 star character although there is no way to guarantee it will be the one you want. Does not have controller support so you will need to set up one with a third party program if you really don't want to use keyboard and mouse. I'm not sure what was going on with the English dub, It seems like they weren't given very good directions on how the characters needs to sound making a lot of the deliveries feel very off and honestly pretty bad. 

tl;dr

Pros:
-Free
-Story
-Characters
-Music
-Collabs
-Lots of Content

Cons:
-Online only
-Grind? (might be a pro if you enjoy a steady grind for more power)
-No way to guarantee a character in Gacha
-English dub was poorly directed for most characters

They have banners that guarantee a 5 star unit although it's 1-3 time only and needs paid premium currency to roll. It's actually bad because after you use that banner if you didn't get the unit you want, you have to roll  on the normal version of the banner which doesn't guarantee a 5 star unit. You can either do a single pull or a 10 pull, a 10 pull guarantees at least a 4 star unit. A set of 10 roll cost 1000 Chronos Stones which is about $32 USD without any promos, but they do have promos monthly. There is no pity system either. If you just want to hit the focus 5 star unit, single pull might be better for you.

If you get unlucky and get a unit that is 3 star out of 5 star or a non "another style" unit, you can upgrade it through game play. Although, it might take a while since the items you need are dungeon drops that are limited entry.

The issue I had is that it feels slow probably because it's a PC port from mobile. A lot of cut scene and the dialogue feels slow to proceed through. Stop it with the flashbacks, its a waste of time especially when it happened just 5 minute ago.
I wish there was a skip text or auto text function because most of the story doesn't interest me. There is a lot of text and spamming space bar gets old.

It sucks you can't sell your old equipment. It just clutter my inventory space when I go to equip my units. Should of been a QOL change a long time ago.

Since this game been out for a while, I'm so behind in the current content stats and I can't do them. So be warned that you probably won't be able to do thing for awhile. You need time to get the new gears and stuff. Might need to get lucky with rolling for new units as well. Since it's a gacha so of course the new units power creep the old units.

This game is on the phone as well and you can transfer data between steam and phone. The thing is that saved data can only be on either or, can't be on both. When transferring data you have to redownload a couple of gbs each time. On the phone there is ads to watch that rewards you either 5-20 Chronos stone, a green/red key each time.

In the end, I still like to play this game because of the play style, dungeon runs, and amount of content it offers.

89709776.review:
[b]EDIT/UPDATE 4/5/21[/b]: WFS has released a statement on the nature of the file, and it's apparently meant to be an anti-cheat kernel driver. Same program should also be removed when the game itself is uninstalled-- however, some players have reported that the wfsdrv.sys file still remains. While an anti-cheat kernel driver in a single-player game seems strange, I can give them the benefit of the doubt that they're doing it to protect their game from being hacked and modded mercilessly. 

Though I'm willing to chalk down the problematic actions to inexperience in coding games for PC (since most of their other games are mobile-based), I still can't recommend the PC version yet to Steam players, as you don't gain much compared to what you can get on the mobile version of the game. 


[b]TL;DR [/b]--- Good free JRPG-lite game, but unknown stuff happens in the background that seems unnecessary to run the game, which makes this PC port kinda sus. Playing game on mobile or emulator recommended until we actually know what’s happening.



This negative recommendation is not due to the game itself— content’s permanent, story’s great, characters are endearing,  gameplay is engaging (though rather grindy and repetitive at times), and the music is sublime. Free collab characters also make the game very easy to run through if you invest in them.

It’s also not because the gacha element of the game: though the rates are very low, there’s no pity system, and 5* characters are usually the only worthwhile ones in the long run, the pool is limited only to characters (since all weapon and item drops can be acquired through in-game grind). Also, once you have the character, they require less investment of hard-to-find materials to become powerful compared to other gacha games. Characters tend to be revisited and given new Styles every so often.

The actual reason for not recommending this game on Steam is due to some behind-the-scenes stuff that happens when the game is launched on your computer— which can be a cause for concern for those that value their privacy. As of this writing, some dedicated players have found that upon launching the game, it tries and fails to install an unknown Windows service, then simply ends up copying a .sys file to a new folder in your Windows system (mine was in C:\Windows\wfsdrv). The file is “locked” and cannot be deleted while Another Eden is installed on your computer. Said file cannot be removed without Administrator privileges, and uninstalling the game does not remove this file— you have to do it manually, for whatever reason. 

What can cause concern is the fact that Another Eden can be played even when the unknown Windows service fails to install. This just raises questions about what the service even does in the first place, as it seems unnecessary in running the game.

At this point in time, nobody is sure what exactly is going on, and reactions among those who found the process and files range from calling it shoddy coding to accusing it of being actual malware/spyware. Whatever the case may be, the game seems to be taking additional unnecessary steps with unknown intentions in order to run on a Windows system in the first place. 

If you still want to play the game (which I highly recommend, because it’s a free-to-play JRPG-lite that will probably remind you of the good ol’ days of classic JRPG gameplay, just with that weird gacha flavor), your best bet is to try it out on mobile or through an emulator.  

Source and a bit more info on findings: [url] https://www.reddit.com/r/AnotherEdenGlobal/comments/mjsggk/steam_version_install_wfsdrv_file_in_your/ [/url]

I recommend this game. I love this game, but there are some pretty serious downsides to overcome that people need to know before trying it out that have nothing to do with the game play. 

First, the data management in this game is the worst I have seen in any game. Why does this game take 25 minutes to download assets? That said I do still love this game. I played it quite a bit on mobile and the same game here on PC. The writing is great, the music is great, and the battle system while it starts off pretty simple ends up being surprisingly deep. Some of the bosses in this game are my favorites out of any turn based RPG. The gatcha doesn't have pity but has much better rates than other games to make up for it. 

Additionally, there is quite a lot of content that is not gated by daily-stamina mechanics: and playing on the PC makes it much easier to code up ways to skip the boring parts since you can do almost everything with just the keyboard. I suppose you can achieve the same thing by emulating the game on PC using something like Bluestacks, but I really like these keyboard controls. 89534837.review:
EDITED REVIEW SINCE MY LAST ENTRY
Now, I am not gonna lie to all you peeps who have never played this game before. This is naturally a port from mobile to PC, but since after my last review, they've fixed the issue with a lot of bug delays so now the game's running smoothly. I don't know if its because of the change of my laptop or they actually did fix the delays.
Here are the cons since everyone seems to be on edge about stuff like this:
-It's a gacha game, however, it is thankfully limited to only the characters.
-There's no skip button for cut scenes and dialogue. You can just rush through but the mere clicks and taps (depending on your game orientation.)
-It is a grinder. (Someone like me doesn't really mind this part, but I know a lot of people get annoyed with a feature like this.) The game's progress can be stunted by the need to grind for items, upgrades and enhancements. (not to mention the fishing sidequest...)
-it might come off as a checklist game (I mean is that there are a lot of steps to progress some of the stories ingame)
Now for the pros:
-You can win this game as a Free to Play (don't believe me? watch some insane players on youtube)
-Story-rich game with a good dynamic of character motivations and development. the characters you get for both in-game and gacha have compelling side-stories and are well written. Fans of classic JRPGs will have a tickle of nostalgia in the writing of its world-building and plot twists.
-You don't have to pay for weapon item upgrades or enhancement (hence the grind)
-Zero Timed Events. You can play your cross-over side stories at your own leasure
-Satiates well for the classic JRPG fans out there. You literally have a samurai frog named Cyrus as a call-back to Chrono Trigger 
As of now, I think it's safe to say this game is good, not perfect, not entirely bad, but good.

Now, for the in-depth review:
I'm gonna say it. This game holds a special place in my heart since I've first played it on mobile. The mechanics of this game is simple but balanced in terms of combat but boy it can be brutal with its tome drops once you enter the special dungeon mechanic. For what its worth, this is a game made to be played at the player's own pace, but because its story-rich, it demands for more reading through cuts scenes.
Speaking of story: this game's storyline can be divided into arcs respectively. Think of the shounen serialisation but in a JRPG format. So far, there are 3 main arcs of the game with 10 episode storylines, 2 side quests 1 ongoing mythos and 4 symphony episodes. And tons of side/character quests. To all you story gamers, this is a treat to play if you're into the JRPG story format.
The premise of this game is basically this:
After the kidnapping of his sister Feinne by the beast king, Aldo tries to save his sister back, only to be transported 100s of years into the future by a mysterious blue spiral of light. Not only did he discover that mankind has established civilisation to the skies, the prosperous future he saw was fated to fall into ruin by some mysterious force, with his sister being the crux of this disastrous fate. Upon his discovery, Aldo and friends are now on a quest to travel through time and space to save Feinne and the lost future while uncovering the mysteries behind the world they live in.

I hope this review can do this game justice. I realise that I might sound like I'm overpraising the game or seeing this game on a tinted lens, but honestly, the surprising depth this game has is outstanding to me. So with that in mind, please give this game a shot.

Do I recommend this game? Yes. Is this port worth it though? Probably not at this point in time.

Many other reviews have put what they like/dislike about this game so I'll go over some of the main pros/cons.

First off, despite this game being a "gacha" game, it really doesn't feel too much like one, there's absolutely no "FOMO." All characters are PERMANENT. All events are also permanent. There's no "Event only" units that only come out for 2 weeks never to be seen again for months-years. There are time-limited rate ups but all units go into a permanent pool. You don't NEED to get multiple dupes of the same unit over and over like other gacha games. I see people complain about the 5* rates(because they're pretty low) but the thing is, throughout the time I've played this on mobile, there's been a few times where we've gotten free 5* select tickets where we could literally pick any old 5* unit. I've also been able to get 5*s through luck with the crystals I've gotten throughout the gameplay(over time). If you really want a 5* support the devs and pay real $ since you will be guaranteed 5* units for paid gems. Also, you don't NEED the 5* version of a unit, it is possible to get the 4* version and then you grind the upgrade materials to upgrade it into its 5* version. The majority of the content can also be completed with the free units you get throughout the game, there's never a feeling like you have to make a team that's "meta" just to be able to complete something.

Cons with the port: No ad rewards, you miss out on the few crystals you could get every day. No Japanese VOs. Capped at 30 fps(I don't know what it is on the phone but 30 fps feels so bad on a PC).

89464863.review:
Another Eden is by far the best mobile game I have ever played. It has a massive amount of content, and while sometimes grindy, most of the grinding is entirely optional, though I typically choose to do it. As it was originally a mobile game, it does have many of the major mobile game pillars, such as a gatcha system and micro-transactions. I personally think the gatcha system here is done very well - 5 star characters have a higher drop rate than most other gatcha games I have seen, and many 4* characters can be upgraded to their 5* version, though this typically requires some of the aforementioned grinding. Paying gives you guaranteed 5* characters instead, and every once in a while there is a special banner that allows you to select any character you want. And if you choose the free-to-play route, every day gives you 20 "chronos stones", the premium currency, 100 of which is a single pull. Of course, you're practically wasting it if you don't save for 1,000 to do a 10 pull that comes with a 4*, and this is where the mobile version is better than the PC port. The mobile version recently got ad support, and by watching 7 ads a day one can get an average of 60 stones a day instead of just 20. So while I recommend Another Eden as a game, I can guarantee a better experience on mobile, as more gatcha draws means more good characters, which means less getting stuck as the endgame slowly suffers from power creep.

The gatcha system is where most people's complaints seem to lie, so I wanted to talk about that first. Outside of the grinding and the monetization, where Another Eden truly shines is it's story. With many wonderfully written characters, an ever-expanding world, and beautiful artwork, AE is easily one of my favorite JRPGs. I have been playing it since it released globally, and I cannot wait to see how it changes in the years to come.

And with that, one final word of advice - beware the fishing grind.

89447638.review:
I never really write reviews, but I really adore this game so I had to :)

I've been playing this game for more than a year now and it's an amazing little game. Another Eden: The Cat Beyond Time And Space is a free to play singleplayer JPRG. Yeah, I said free to play because although it's a gacha game, you can finish everything in the game with the free characters and if that doesn't interest you, as I'm writing this review I have 119 units as a free to play player so it's not like you can't get any units if you're not paying. (Also there are some pretty good free units in the game.)

I see that many people already said a lot of things about the game and I wouldn't say those things again, so let me just talk about why I love this game and why I didn't left it although I tried out a looot of other gacha games.

> STORY
First of all, I adore the design of this game.
The story starts as any generic JRPG, but then the whole time traveling comes in and everything just changes; the main character, Aldo has to help the people around him and he can't even go back to his own time. I absolutely love that the map has three time layers and you can see how the things and places slowly change under the years (and some quests even revolve around this feature).
The main story is pretty good, but it can become a bit confusing especially because (right now) you can't read back about what happened previously. Sometimes it's a bit stupid because right after you save the world you just go around being a "Time-Traveling Garbage Man", but I guess it's just a RPG thing :D
The side quests are really really good though; you can ask everyone and they will say that they are in love with the IDA series or the Time Mine. They are really well written and you do not just unlock a free unit by playing them, but you can get a lot of rewards from them as well (but it's rather grindy in most cases).
There are also world quests, collaborations (right now with Persona 5 Royal and some of the Tales series) and character quests for every unit who's at least a 4* (these can range from 2 to 4 quests per character) and they unlock new skills.

> WORLD
I think a lot of people look at this game and when they see that the units are chibis they just ignore the game. Not gonna lie, I would die to see a 3D fighting game spin-off, but it's a very awesome game as it is. From the gacha mobile games I've played, this had the most fun combat. It's turn based combat so a lot of people will skip this, but nothing is better than the feeling when you finally beat that big bad monster you tried to beat for day or weeks.
The places you visit in the game are really nice and some of them are straight up gorgeous, like the Corinda Plains, Moonlight Forest or [spoiler] Hismena's Dreamworld [/spoiler]. They are not just very appealing visually, but the background music... oh the music.
The music is one of the strongest points of the game in my opinion. Last year my most listened song was Cage of Blue Roses, so I guess that says everyhing (also Alphecca slaps).
I also love how much content is in the game. I don't think there's anyone in the community who finished all of them. There are a lot of grinds, like the side stories, fishing, mining and so many secrets and secret questlines, that I wouldn't be surprised if there were still some hiding out there.
Another big point is that no content is time-locked. Every quest, sidequest, collab, unit, you can get everything anytime.

> THE COMMUNITY
I'm always pleasantly surprised how nice the people are on the Reddit page. This is one of the chillest gaming communities I've ever seen. There is a very well maintained and updated Wiki page, loads of guides and megathreads, and everyone who I talked with was very friendly and helpful. We also have a great relationship with the devs and they post Q&As and stuff like that regularly (just last week we had a meme competition :D ). There are no shipwars, no rushing people, no talking down on other's 'small damage' or team composition (only some small "waifu wars", but we all know that [strike] Isuka [/strike] Heena is best girl) like ehemmm another rather popular gacha game.

It's a comfortable place. It's a comfortable game.

Now about the port.
Sadly the Steam version doesn't seem to be as good as the mobile version. You start up the game and you just know it that it wasn't made for PC. Only the English voices are here what I wouldn't mind, but since all of the collab characters are only voiced in Japanese they are mute here. Sadly you also can't log in the same account on both mobile and PC unless you want to log in and re-download everything everytime, but I guess if you want a fresh start you can do that here.

All in all, it's a very nice little game and I enjoy playing with it, but do not look at it as a GI or AK, it's not those games. The Reddit and Discord community is welcoming and we also have a small Twitter one, but those are mostly the update notices.
It doesn't hurt to give it a go and if you have any questions, we are all happy to help! <3

((now then, where is the merch WFS? give us those nice shirts!!!!))

89439609.review:
Disclaimer: This is primarily a review based off of the IOS/Android version of the game. So far I have not run into any issues with the steam port but I have not played the steam version as extensively.

Let's get a few things out of the way first:
1. This is a mobile game port
2. This game uses a gacha/lootbox system for characters
3. Only English voices are available here while the mobile version let's you choose between EN and JP VAs

Despite that, it manages to be one of the better f2p mobile games out there. Unlike most other mobile games this one does not have any form of auto combat, PvP, co-op or limited time events. It is purely a solo jrpg experience.

In terms of story it is quite good provided you can stomach some of the more standard jrpg tropes. Another Eden is sometimes called the spiritual successor to Chrono Trigger (as you may be able to tell from the scenario writer) so it shares many common themes like time travel and FrogDude. All characters above 3*/common rarity have their own character stories too which can range from slice of life/comedy to robot genocide.
While the main story can at times feel predictable, the Episode side quests are where it really shines. Episodes are individually packaged story arcs about specific side characters or organizations. They usually contain new explorable zones, side quests, minigames, free characters and a farmable dungeon. The only downside to Episodes is that grinding the dungeon for all available rewards can take a long time. Also, there are special collaboration Episodes for Persona 5 and the TalesOf series. All the collab characters are free and do not need to be obtained from the gacha system which is a plus.

When it comes to combat you're probably not going to be blown away by its complexity or build diversity. There are 5 main elements: Fire, Wind, Water, Earth and Neutral. There are also 3 'sub' elements Shadow, Lightning and Crystal. Characters generally have 1 element and can equip 3~ skills which cost MP to use. In battle, you can bring 6 characters split between 4 frontline and 2 reserve units. Characters on reserve do not take damage and recover a portion of their HP and MP per turn. When a character changes position from reserve to front, they activate a character unique Valor Chant skill that can range from damaging enemies, debuffing their attack, or healing the party. For tough fights, you need to carefully plan out when to change character positions while also maintaining the right amount of mitigation to survive. Unfortunately you won't experience any of the truly difficult fights until endgame as most of the time you can blitz through bosses with the use of Another Force. Another Force/Time Stop is a gauge that is charged each time you attack the enemy and once activated allows you to fire off skills in rapid succession. Damage done in this state is amplified significantly and with the right set of buffs/debuffs you can potentially do millions of damage in a single turn. All in all, there is some mechanical complexity to the combat but early content can be face rolled pretty easily. 

Equipment is rather simple with each character only requiring 1 weapon and 1 armor piece. Later on you are given more build options by crafting  'Grasta' (aka Runes) but you won't see this until chapter 50+. Otherwise Manifest Weapons (weapons that buff older characters' skills) require exp grinding which isn't too horrible with the exp dungeons available.

The music is excellent with every new zone or town having a unique theme. The actual full sound track is probably 140+ songs. Graphics wise it's retro-esque with a 2.5d world and hand drawn chibi style sprites. The character portrait art is very well done and there is a lot of diversity between characters from the past/present/future.

Now, the gacha. Gacha rates range from 3.5%-5% for max rarity 5*/SSR characters. Characters of the max rarity can also be obtained at 4*/SR rarity and later upgraded through farming materials in game. Duplicate characters only increase light/shadow or base stats by a few points. Some characters can also have alternate forms called "Another Style" which can change their role in combat drastically. As many other reviewers have noted, the gacha simply sucks as there is no guarantee to obtain characters you want. Hopefully this changes in the future as generally the older a game is the more generous it becomes but for now it can be frustrating if you are particularly unlucky.

TLDR the gacha and somewhat simplified combat system holds back what is surprisingly a well crafted old school jrpg with lots of content to enjoy. If you can refrain from spending and play the game casually there is a lot to like. I recommend just trying it out yourself, it is free after all. Whether the pros outweigh the cons is up to you. Happy hunting!

P.S Always create an account transfer code and store it in a safe place.

89435873.review:
I am writing this review as someone who has poured hundreds of hours into the mobile version of this game. I have played since mid-2019 and experienced the game's highs and lows. Another Eden is a singleplayer gacha JRPG and it feels cheaply produced compared to JRPGs that are more polished and are more ethically monetized.

[h1]The PC Version[/h1]
The PC/steam port of this game runs perfectly fine, but lacks customization found in other JRPGS. A lot of menus require dragging your mouse pointer around and the game does not even give you the option to navigate with key presses. The PC version does not allow you to change keybinds period. This is especially annoying when fighting enemies since the same key that selects the unit is also the same key that selects the move they use ('1' is first party member as well as first move). Overall, I think if you wanted to play this game on a PC, you should definitely play on an emulator. Not only can you customize your keybinds to your heart's content, you can set up macros that automatically use AOE attacks for instance.

[h1]Gacha[/h1]
For those who do not know, "gacha" is basically the anime version of "loot boxes" or "card packs". You spend some of the premium currency the game gives you for a randomized chance of getting certain characters. You will find that many people argue that it is not necessary for players to use the gacha because the game gives you really good free characters. While this is true, this issue stills lies that a vast majority of new characters being released are much better than the free characters and that they are [b]ONLY[/b] available through the gacha system. Each character summoned through the gacha has a rarity of 3, 4, or 5 stars. The level cap for a character is tied to their current rarity and only a select few of the characters from the pool of 3 or 4 star characters can be promoted to 5-stars. Very irritatingly, this means that a majority of a the characters you summon are negligible since they can not be promoted and as such can not reach the maximum level (80). 

The distribution rates for each rarity in the gacha system are also very miserable. Each summon nets you a a 2% chance for a 5-star, 40% chance for a 4-star and 57.6% chance for a 3-star. I personally dislike gacha monetization and as such have never spent a cent throughout the many gacha games I have played, this one being no exception. This game does alright with giving players the premium currency for free, but only through the use of ads (which are not part of the PC release).

One more note: to promote a character from 4 stars to 5 stars, it requires 5 "chant scripts". The only renewable way to obtain these scripts is through Another Dungeons, which I will cover in the "grind" section of my review.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The initial story is well written and produced, as you would expect from Masato Kato who has previously worked on Chrono Trigger. Unfortunately I think that the story past chapter 26 is sub-par compared to what came before. You also rarely get free characters from the main campaign after this point in the story. The side quests are fun ways to get to know the towns you're visiting or the characters in your party, but it's really unfortunate that every single character side quest boils down to the same exact formula. You start the quest -> Dialogue -> Go somewhere else -> Fight a monster -> Go somewhere else -> End

Also an important QoL feature that is missing is the ability to skip cutscenes. You have to keep clicking in order to progress through dialogue.

Purely looking at this from a design perspective, these quests are utterly monotonous. At least the writing for these quests is usually good. You find out something new about the character and might explain some of their personality or odd behavior.

There are also various entire "side stories" which are entire mini-campaigns that take place in locations separate from the main story. The stories here are typically well-written but are unfortunately plagued by a grind requirement in order to progress through them. For most of these stories, you have to grind a certain amount of their respective key item in order to access the next chapter. And just to nudge you into using the gacha system more, having specific gacha characters will increase the rate at which you collect these key items. 

[h1]Combat[/h1]
In regards to party customization, Another Eden does a phenomenal job. You can have 6 members in a party and 4 will fight while 2 stay in the backline. When you switch a frontline unit for someone in the back, they will perform a "valor chant", which can be a party/individual buff, an enemy debuff, or even an AOE attack. Another Force is also a cool mechanic but more often than not just boils down to button mashing.

However it should be noted that your party customization is tied to how lucky/how much you spend on the gacha system to get new characters. Units obtained through gacha are also often much better than free characters that accomplish similar roles. 

[h1]Grind[/h1]
The gameplay loop is absolutely horrible. You get 4 green keys and 4 red keys every day (you can only hold up to 9 and 5 respectively). These are used for accessing Another Dungeons which are just mini-dungeons of areas you have already explored. Unfortunately, every single dungeon run is the exact same experience. The same starting locations, the same path to the end, the same enemies, and it becomes tiring really quickly. The real kicker is that you have to make the most of these keys because you need the promotion items as well as materials to craft weapons that the dungeon drops. 

There is also the light and shadow system which is just extra BS that I won't get into. Just know that it only benefits players who summon duplicates of the same hero (usually paying users) or people that grind dungeons every day for months.

I covered the grind from side-stories in my "story" section and how it creates a problem for the game to sell you a solution. 

[h1]Soundtrack and Voice Acting[/h1]
The music is excellent. It's very recognizable and I love listening to it outside of playing the game. You will be hard pressed to find pieces of soundtrack on youtube that aren't enjoyable.

The voice acting on the other hand is where WFS really skimped out. Very few portions of the game are actually voiced, almost all dialogue in the game just has music playing with the occasional sound effect. The only times you hear voice acting is when you summon a character and once every turn of combat. It's really quite disappointing if you compare it to JRPGs like P5, Tales, and Octopath Traveler.

They have hired many unproven english voice actors to do the english dub of this game. This is further supported by the fact that they did not get the english voice acting done for the P5 or Tales collaboration characters. That being said, the people who say that the english dub is horrible or garbage are completely exaggerating. The quality is not up to something you would expect from something like Funimation or Crunchyroll, but it is certainly not bad enough that it's "unplayable". 

Another thing that these dub haters like to ignore is that there are [b]NO SUBTITLES[/b] for the Japanese voices. So whenever you do hear these JP voices (keep in mind it's literally one line per turn of combat), you won't even know what they are saying. The steam version does lack the JP voice lines, but I assume this was because WFS saw a vast majority of players keeping the English voices turned on and so they didn't bother adding the JP voices. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Another Eden is a story-rich and incredibly fun JRPG a for the first few hours and features a large cast of characters that make the combat incredibly diverse. Unfortunately it comes with many caveats including the horrible monetization through gacha and extensive grind to really progress efficiently.

89415490.review:
Day 2 review, subject to change after more updates and time in game.

I played this game when it launched about 2 years ago and played it on and off on its mobile version. Here's how I feel about it and how I feel about its mobile port after some play time in it.

Pros: If you like classic JRPGs like Chrono Trigger or anything similar of a random encounter JRPG, you might like this game. If you like mindlessly grinding for materials to gain rewards, then this is your game. If you like collaborations with Persona 5, Tales series, and other future franchises, then this is your game. If you like gacha games where doing achievements to acquire rainbow gems just to pull and gain nothing but salt pleases you, then this is your game.

Cons: If you hate gacha games where using gems to summon and all you get is salt sickens you, then this is not your game. If you don't like English voices, this might not be your game. If you don't like grinding your character's EXP and rather feed EXP to your characters, then this is not your game. If you don't like simple-style 2D sprites, then this is not your game. If you don't like turn based RPGs (this is preferential) then this is not your game.

My impressions of this PC version are as follows...at this moment in time the PC version feels like it needs to undergo several platform patches before fully feeling like at better platform to play on, as well as adding Borderless Widescreen, adding back the different voice overs that mobile had like Japanese VAs, decreasing lag and stutter, as well as fixing other smaller bugs like not being able launch it one the first attempt whereas it launches on the 2nd attempt. Overall I feel like it is a better idea to play AE on mobile devices or emulators for the optimal experience until the PC platform is fixed, unless you are new to the game and are enjoying the experience on PC just fine or you phone's battery is just awful.

And here's some personal words of mine....play it first, form your own opinion, and don't take someone else's before you form a fake opinion and ruin a chance a play a game you might like or don't like.

For now this review is only based me playing game on mobile and android emulators. If i find something bad with PC port that will be edited in later.
And i have used tiny bit money to get star dream encounter banners.

Lets start with the elephant in the room.
Is/Was this a mobile game? YES
Does it have gacha? YES
Does it update content like GaaS? YES
Can it be played F2P? Yes
Stamina system? NO, though is limited on how many dungeons per day.
I will cover all these later on, but i know some people will skip the game just because of this. 

Gameplay:
This is a turn based JRPG mobile, with heavy team building to overcome hard optional stuff. Since it is turned based, being mobile game did not hold that gameplay back in any way.
Gameplay start of pretty simpel at start, make team of 4 frontline unit and 2 backline units. Frontline unit are ones doing the battle, while backline units are there to switch with frontline unit or replace em if they die.
Then comes Valor chant system, which is system you should not over look, even though it not important at start. Valor chant is attack or effect that happens when switching character in.
Lastly on top we get Another force, which simpelly a bar you fill and then active to get a period where you can spam skill nonstop without boss attacking back
Now later one there wil come more system like grasta(think of it as extra gear) and zones, though zones can show up very early depeding on your gacha luck, it is not needed for a long time

Story:
Another eden is not called spiritual successor to Chrono Trigger for no reason. It is a time traveling story by Masato Kato, and i personally couldn´t put game down first time i startet to play and always keep coming back for new story content.
For story there is a lot, first you got a nice long main story, 1 mythos, 10 sidestory, 3 symphony(this is collab, 2 are persona 5 and 1 is Tales of series), tons of side quest, 3 to 5 personal quest for 5* units and most likely forgot something

Music:
For me Another eden OST is good, while i am no music expert. I simpelly judge this on fact i every now and then go find some songs to play in background when doing other stuff

Content:
Already said there is a lot of stories to go through. But that is not only content in another eden 
here some example;
Fishing
Hard boss battle/Manifastion weapon battle
Lord of Mana VRMMO
"cat battle"
Theatre
Dungeon runs (you get 1 red key and 1 green key each 6 hours)
Farming grasta, exp, gear and so on

An important note here, content in Another eden is permanent, so you will never miss out if you decide to take break from the game
Most people know one thing that common for gacha games, is stamina system to limited you. Good news is another eden does not have a stamina system, so you can keep playing the stories or go fishing without worrying about being forced to stop. But i Dungeon do have a limit on em, most likely because where you get stuff to upgrade character from 4 to 5*, light/shadow farming and grasta stuff.

Mmonetization:
Ok this a big point for a lot of people. Game is a gacha, i have seen better rates and i seen worse, while they never cheap either. No pity system, but all 5* can also drop as 4*(often called 4,5*) which you later can upgrade 5*. So overall you will be getting 5* at some point, new players got a lot chronos stone to earn
There is free and paid banner. Only difference is most time paid banner guarantee 5* at end, but for you own sake, always read info the banner before pulling.
If you decide to get some paid games, my advice is. Only use it on Paid stones on fateful encounter that 100% drops a 5* at end. But if you only go buy  stones once or twice it is worth saving those paid stones for when either star dream encounter or "100% chance for this unit" banners. Because star dream you get 10 pull + "pick your 5* ticket" and while other banner will Guarantee what 5* you get, so with these 2 you always know what you get.
BE CAREFUL, if you forget to pay attention you can waste paid stones on free banner and you will  regret that i suspect. Though if you whale go ahead


F2P:
Now also a big topic for this type of game. Can you play without ever paying? Yes
First of all, you will get some 5* with amount chrono stone you get as new players and you can get 50 stone minimum each day. Even if you are one those insanely unlucky people that never gets a  good pulls, Another eden is filled with character that can be earn and upgrade to 5* from just playing and never touching gacha. 
Fast checking i think there is something like 26+ with some of em being top tier units and covering pretty well since you can get fire and slash zone without gacha.
Difficulty to get that free units varies a lot, but collab units in general are not hard to get and will set you well up for later content.

89412051.review:
[b]EDIT:[/b] Steam version includes anticheat kernel (kinda reasonable 4 gacha), installs to Windows folder & not removed properly when uninstall (rather less so). Prev edit removed, charlimit. Orig review below.


This is a port of a mobile game. I personally like this game, but I'm leaving this as a negative review because the downsides really are quite steep and I believe negative reviews are more useful overall for finding out why you might not want to spend your money on a game. Out of respect for the reader's time I'll get things out of the way in reverse order from how these are usually listed:

[b]The Ugly[/b]

[list]
[*] This is a gacha game. All the money is made off lootboxes for units, the rates are very, very low, and there's no pity system to guarantee a unit eventually other than the (paid only) banners that have guaranteed 5-stars, only some of which let you pick which one you get. New units or new versions of old units are introduced every couple weeks and they have powercreep to keep players spending. The global version's several months behind the JP version so you generally have some idea what to save up for (however the devs did recently release a unit to global before JP so this isn't a guarantee), you only need one version of a unit at any rarity to be able to unlock their other forms through gameplay, and the game gives you a lot of free rolls through the achievement system, but that's cold comfort to people who save for months or spend hundreds of dollars only to get nothing but robots and Pom. If you're not willing to support a game that uses a predatory monetization model no matter how good the actual game is, you're best off looking elsewhere.
[*] The PC port is catastrophically unstable, at least for me. My copy crashed right after I finished transferring my save from mobile and unlocked the achievements, then decided I needed to redownload the entire thing from scratch, which I didn't bother doing. The entire rest of this review is based off what I've heard others say about the early access trial, since due to a few reasons that will be detailed below I was going to switch straight back to mobile after becoming eligible to leave a review anyway.
[/list]

[b]The Bad[/b]

[list]
[*] The game's an 8GB download but when you launch it you're stuck with the same amount of downloading as if you were using the mobile app, which is not an 8GB upfront download. Kind of defeats the point, especially if you get stuck in a downloading >100% progress loop which is known to happen on the mobile version as well.
[*] The game can be [i]incredibly[/i] grindy if you're trying to get all the rewards. That's not necessarily a bad thing if you're into it, some of the rewards really are more than good enough to make the time investment worth it, and some of the grinds are much less painful than others, but then you get things like fishing which takes over a week if you're doing it optimally, months to years if realistic, and doesn't get you anything but an admittedly large amount of gacha currency and a unit that's long since been power crept into irrelevancy. Thankfully this sort of grind only really happens with optional content, and the rewards from the worst grinds can generally be replaced with far less grindy alternatives.
[*] Max level is tied to rarity, so once you're past the launch story anything that isn't max rarity is going to be basically worthless. The story units don't unlock their max rarity forms for quite a while (some still haven't) and then need you to grind to actually use them, though these days there are other free units that you get at max rarity much earlier that also skip most of the grind.
[*] Upgrading gacha units requires Chant Scripts, which have an obscenely low drop rate from the daily dungeons which are this game's main time gate. There are quite a few guaranteed chant drops but they tend to run afoul of the previous point.
[*] Global's on an accelerated release schedule to catch up with JP. This seems to have been slowing down somewhat recently now that we're only a couple months behind, but it has meant less saved up login rewards for global players compared to JP players. And that's only partially offset by knowing what to save for.
[*] The Steam version doesn't have the option for Japanese voices. The biggest issue with this is that there are collab characters from Persona 5 and the Tales series, as well as skits from the Tales collab, that are completely unvoiced now. It's not entirely clear why they decided to do this, it's not as though PC has more space limitations than mobile. Maybe it's a licensing thing?
[*] You can't rebind the controls, so if you don't like the layout you're out of luck. This might get addressed in a patch later.
[*] This one's closer to neutral since whether it's good or bad depends on the individual, but the Steam version doesn't have ads. The ads in the mobile version are fully optional (though one of them has a prompt you have to close once a day when you log in) and give you currency for gacha rolls.
[/list]

[b]The Good[/b]

[list]
[*] The launch story is one big homage to Chrono Trigger, and in fact several of the staff of CT are leads for this game. It really shows in the [i]extremely[/i] high quality of the gameplay, music, and writing, barring a couple spots in specific sidestories where the translation is known to have been rushed for a simultaneous JP + global release. Don't worry about the game having no identity of its own, almost everything other than the launch story (AKA part 1 of the main story) and the collabs gives the game its own distinct identity.
[*] The level of polish and attention to detail is generally extremely high. The game reacts to whether or not you've met a character before and how far you've gotten through party members' sidestories when you do something involving them, and almost always gets it right.
[*] Unlike virtually every other gacha game in existence, there is no such thing as time limited content in this game (apart from banners and currency campaigns). All characters join the spook pool for every subsequent banner once released. All stories, dungeons, and fights are permanently accessible, to the point where any maps that get closed as part of the story get added to the End of Time homage area to make sure you don't lose out on anything. And this game has a [i]lot[/i] of content for you to dive into.
[*] The game is 100% beatable with free units, several of which are top tier even in the JP meta. Some particularly insane players have even beaten many of the superbosses with them, and I do mean insane because it can take upwards of an hour of perfect play to do that.
[*] The devs frequently release new versions of old units or manifest weapons that upgrade the old versions outright. Sometimes they even give max rarity forms to units that didn't have them before. They don't always bring old units back into the meta (poor Shion), but they succeed more often than not, and the effort is appreciated regardless.
[*] Related to the previous, some old units are near the top of the meta even today. Most relevant to new players at the time of writing, Suzette (with her manifest weapon, which is considered one of the easiest to obtain since it was one of the first to be released) is an extremely strong and useful unit to this day and is presently being given to new accounts for free, albeit at sub-max rarity so you'd still have to spend chants to upgrade her or get lucky with rolls.
[*] The game's word salad of a title actually makes sense once you have the context for it.
[*] Myrus is a precious (and piping hot) cinnamon roll.
[/list]

Hopefully I've helped you come to a decision. If you decide to give the game a shot, all you need to know is that rerolling isn't necessary, Bivette is the best pick from the tutorial summon, and you should set up a transfer ID as soon as possible and save it somewhere safe so you won't risk losing your account.
